review_preview: A dinner at Casa Benigna entails more than just amazing food and service. This beautiful hidden gem will leave you glowing with happiness when you leave. From the moment you walk in the staff are extremely nice and accommodating. Throughout your meal, they will constantly...
review_full: A dinner at Casa Benigna entails more than just amazing food and service. This beautiful hidden gem will leave you glowing with happiness when you leave. From the moment you walk in the staff are extremely nice and accommodating. Throughout your meal, they will constantly check in on you to make sure you are satisfied with your meal. Furthermore, they are extremely nice and love to meet customers! Throughout my meal I was able to get to know each of the waiters personally, the manager Eduardo, the owner Norberto, the original owner Carmin (now 92 years old but as sweet as ever), and was even invited to come back to meet the chefs and watch them make paella.  On top of amazing and personal service, Casa Benigna serves incredible food. Their signature dish is the paella which sticks to the pan, giving the rice a nice crispy taste and wonderful flavor. Regardless of what you order here you will leave satisfied as the portion sizes are large and come with a variety of fresh side dishes.  I cannot stress enough how great this restaurant is. It combines a fine dining experience with personal service that ultimately makes you never want to leave. Definitely make a reservation and check this place out if you are in town. You will not regret it.

review_preview: Recommended by our hotel, a 10 minute taxi ride in a cold and unassuming neighborhood. No sign, you must knock on the door to enter.  Norberto, the owner is warm, explains his philosophy for building a team dedicated to great food and service. Paella is...
review_full: Recommended by our hotel, a 10 minute taxi ride in a cold and unassuming neighborhood. No sign, you must knock on the door to enter. Norberto, the owner is warm, explains his philosophy for building a team dedicated to great food and service. Paella is the menu focus. We had a smoked salmon appetizer which had been marinated in herbs and then smoked, which had a great flavor. The tomatico(bruschetta), which was very flavorful. Four of us ordered two paella dishes, chicken and then seafood. The homemade, assorted bread with olive oil and balsamic vinegar was outstanding. We met Norberto's beautiful granddaughter and his 92 year-old mother who is elegant and beautiful. Casa Benigna is an enormous success because of the unique patented cooking pan/devices, great ingredients, a team-based philosophy and great attention to Norberto's clients' enjoyment and needs. We capped our meal with a tour of the restaurant, a complimentary glass of champagne. As we walked out we reserved a table for our return to Madrid in one week.

title_review: Perfect place to relax and have delicious beers :)
review_preview: We visited this place off a recommendation (from Fernando, owner of Collage cocktail bar in Barcelona) and were not disappointed! Owner Javier and his wife have an amazing thing going here - craft brews from all over Europe (and some from the US) in both...
review_full: We visited this place off a recommendation (from Fernando, owner of Collage cocktail bar in Barcelona) and were not disappointed! Owner Javier and his wife have an amazing thing going here - craft brews from all over Europe (and some from the US) in both draft and bottle form. Best of all, the owner has some of his own beers for purchase! Must say, his are some of the most original beers I've ever had - and they taste great too! An IPA brewed with mustard, and a brown ale (very tactfully) brewed with hot pepper. Highly recommended that you order their homemade beers if you go in. We had them in bottles, but they mentioned that occasionally they also have them on tap. Either way, worth a visit simply to have their stuff. We can't speak to the cheeses, since we never ordered any, but they looked delicious from afar :)  Go to Bee Beer, order some house brews, and spend some time talking with the owners - you won't regret it.

title_review: Excellent beer in the good beer desert that is Madrid
review_preview: Who would have thought the day would come when American beer was better than European? Well, that day has arrived. Coming from California, I am used to delicious beer such as Sculpin, Lagunitas and even Sierra Nevada. Spanish beer is like Pabst Blue Ribbon. Insipid....
review_full: Who would have thought the day would come when American beer was better than European? Well, that day has arrived. Coming from California, I am used to delicious beer such as Sculpin, Lagunitas and even Sierra Nevada. Spanish beer is like Pabst Blue Ribbon. Insipid. Boring. Someone recommended Bee Beer to me and I finally got there two days ago. This little bar, owned by a Basque guy and his Venezuelan wife, has about a dozen craft beers on tap. I tried the Spanish IPA and was very pleased. A regular ca√±a at a regular bar would cost at most two euros and this one cost five but it was well worth it! I will be back again and again.

review_preview: The best craft beer bar I've ever been to. We walked in at about 2 o'clock, planning on having one or two drinks; ended up staying for 5 hours and truly having an afternoon to remember!The selection of beer was magnificent. 7 varied taps,...
review_full: The best craft beer bar I've ever been to. We walked in at about 2 o'clock, planning on having one or two drinks; ended up staying for 5 hours and truly having an afternoon to remember! The selection of beer was magnificent. 7 varied taps, a fridge full of Spanish beer, and a fridge full of international beers. Between the 3 of us we must have shared about 17 beers after deciding to try as many as we could after our initial couple. We tried all sorts from sours, to stouts, to IPA's, to barley wines; all lovely. While we were there the very friendly bar lady kept us well nourished with stunning coconut peanuts, cream cheese and olives. She also let us choose our own songs on the stereo which made the experience that bit more special. It is owned by a very pleasant family who came along in the evening and chatted to us. We loved the whole time we spent in there. If we're ever in Madrid again we'll be sure to pop in and have a few more beers! Muchos gracias/Diolch yn fawr.

review_preview: Casa Benigna is a fabulous, one-of-a-kind restaurant.  We were thrilled with our dinner here.  It‚Äôs in a rather unprepossessing, working-class neighborhood, and we were a bit disconcerted when the taxi driver let us out in what looked like the middle of nowhere.  But the low...
review_full: Casa Benigna is a fabulous, one-of-a-kind restaurant. We were thrilled with our dinner here. It‚Äôs in a rather unprepossessing, working-class neighborhood, and we were a bit disconcerted when the taxi driver let us out in what looked like the middle of nowhere. But the low rents in that area allow the owner to put his money totally into the food and into his customer‚Äôs experience. We had the meal of a life-time here. The specialty is a rather unusual, dry paella. But other dishes off the menu were stupendous, too. The smoked salmon (which is smoked right there in the kitchen as it‚Äôs being grilled for you) was to die for. The eggplant was cooked perfectly. We loved the blood sausage, too, even though it‚Äôs something we never would order‚Äîit was a complimentary dish. The chocolate mousse-like dessert was fabulous. This was one of the best meals we‚Äôve had in years, and it was made more special because the owner stopped off at our table to chat several times, and eventually invited us back into the kitchen to meet the staff and enjoy a glass of free cava. I doubt he has the time to do that every night, but it was obvious that he‚Äôs devoted his life to his restaurant and loves to enhance his customers‚Äô experience, and it shows. If I were rich enough, I‚Äôd jump on a plane to Madrid just to have dinner at Casa Benigna. It‚Äôs truly extraordinary.

review_preview: This restaurant was absolutely amazing!! It was very authentic and had a beautiful ambience! We were welcomed by Edward and given a tour of the whole restaurant including the kitchen, all was incredibly clean. We sat down to our table and had bread and a...
review_full: This restaurant was absolutely amazing!! It was very authentic and had a beautiful ambience! We were welcomed by Edward and given a tour of the whole restaurant including the kitchen, all was incredibly clean. We sat down to our table and had bread and a selection of vegetables with dip! We were brought over the biggest bucket of butter I have ever seen and this was ready butter! We were then brought a welcome (vegetable soup) which was lovely. I ordered a starter of duck and aubergine which was so tasty! We were also given some croquets to try again these very very tasty! We had the lobster paella for main and it was incredible! So much flavour and served dry (the traditional way). We then had strawberry sorbet for dessert which they brought out with a candle and sang happy birthday in English and gave us complimentary champagne for my birthday! Overall amazing and if your in Madrid you need to visit!

review_preview: Thanks to other traveller tips, we chose this speciality paella restaurant before others: and it paid us back with perfection. I've eaten, and I've cooked paella, but nothing compares to this. Some may get a shock when they say that the finished dish is flat,...
review_full: Thanks to other traveller tips, we chose this speciality paella restaurant before others: and it paid us back with perfection. I've eaten, and I've cooked paella, but nothing compares to this. Some may get a shock when they say that the finished dish is flat, a thin layer of crispy, succulent, delicious rice, with small bits of seafood/poultry/whatever your choose, spread throughout - not huge pieces on top of the dish. But oh my, it is just the best we've ever eaten, including mine! It's balanced in flavour, delicate yet almost robust and not overpowering with saffron, and just melt in your mouth. As I say, small serving, but that's all you need. The delivery and serving is a treat: the waiter scrapes the pan, gets all the crunchy bits mixed into the whole, and Voila! there it is. The team are surprisingly all Filipino, no problem then with efficiency and happy attitude. The maitre d' is super efficient, no messing around or delays here. So don't expect a leisurely, romantic meal: this is a serious foody restaurant - with an excellent wine selection. Try the asparagus entree (yummy), and their home made olive oil with the delicious bread: just leave room for the paella.

The staff were friendly and attentive, my glass did not go unfilled all night. The bread was a little dry, and I found the choc mousse desert a little too rich with a bit of a funny aftertaste. All in all good, but I think you could find better at a lesser price.

title_review: Good pizza at a decent price
review_preview: This is just a place that has unusually good pizza. I am usually sceptical for "great pizza" and when I go to such a place I always order pizza margherita because with very few ingredients it needs to be really well made in order to...
review_full: This is just a place that has unusually good pizza. I am usually sceptical for "great pizza" and when I go to such a place I always order pizza margherita because with very few ingredients it needs to be really well made in order to taste right. This place has got it. The dough is very good, thin and crispy, otherwise it was perfectly made and served as soon as it came out. Ensalata Caprese as well: has to be extra fresh for it to stand out. They had some very tasty tomatoes and the basil was fresh and had the right taste. Deserts were not particularly special, I skipped as I was full but only tried from friends.  Service is quick, not particularly friendly but professional: the place was packed, and I think it usually is. They take orders fast, bring the food and came by once to see if we wanted more drinks etc.  Decoration, well its a matter of taste, I did not find it particularly engaging but we were lucky to sit at the only table at the window at street level, so we had a lot of nice bright light. Otherwise regardless that this small place was packed it is well kept and clean. A very good restaurant when walking the area as it is in the middle of a shopping district and is well communicated.

review_preview: I have to write this review to do justice to the unbelievably wonderful dinner we just experienced. Casa Benigna is THAT good. Pulled up TripAdvisor app and starting searching ‚ÄúPaella‚Äù as we were having craving for real authentic Spanish food. 550 5xstars ratings and lots...
review_full: I have to write this review to do justice to the unbelievably wonderful dinner we just experienced. Casa Benigna is THAT good.  Pulled up TripAdvisor app and starting searching ‚ÄúPaella‚Äù as we were having craving for real authentic Spanish food. 550 5xstars ratings and lots of good reviews and coincidentally 5 min walk from my hotel. We went searching for Casa Benigna.  If not for Google maps, we would never have noticed it was a restaurant behind that inconspicuous huge wooden door along a residential street.  Tapped the iron knob a couple of times and we were greeted by a very friendly staff (Ryan) who told us this place is ‚Äúreservation only‚Äù much to our dismay. I tried to plea for a corner table as we were hungry but were politely turned down. Left my number and made a reservation for next day lunch.  15min later as we were still walking around the neighbourhood looking for food (and restaurants with English menus), the phone rang and Ryan was on the line. Someone cancelled and he could take us! Wow!!! He bothered to call us back...! Fast Forward. Casa Benigna is decorated like a traditional Spanish home with books and photo frames donning every corner of the place. Starters were delicious bread, biscuits, chips (real thick potato pieces) and salads. The Olives and Avocado cream were fresh.  They gave a bucket (yes a large bucket!) of home made butter to go with everything.  Finally the Seafood Paella recommended by Ryan was the best meal this trip, probably better than any Paella we‚Äôve had before. The seafood was painstakingly chopped into pieces and the rice done to perfection.  This place is a 100% must try when you are in Madrid. The Paella, The Ambience and The Service - .  Gracias!

title_review: Best meal we had in Spain
review_preview: Make dinner reservations at Casa Benigna. Do it now. You will not be disappointed.I do not normally open a review so strongly, but this was the best meal of our ten days in Spain. It was not only a meal, but an experience -...
review_full: Make dinner reservations at Casa Benigna. Do it now. You will not be disappointed. I do not normally open a review so strongly, but this was the best meal of our ten days in Spain. It was not only a meal, but an experience - perfect for a couple looking for a quiet and unique night together. We will stay with the door. At first we thought that maybe our Uber driver has made a mistake. The restaurant facade is so unassuming, and the door was locked. Using the knocker, the friendly staff opened the door to a unique and charming establishment. Each table has some unique decorations that make it special. Our table was set and waiting for us, not only with place settings but with the start of our first course - beads and olives. Olive oil, balsamic, and French butter soon followed. The next course was a small bowl of vegetable and cod soup. It was lovely, and included in the 6‚Ç¨ per person cover charge, as was the bread. Next we had our starter. We chose the herring. The marinated herring had a more subtle flavor than we get in the USA, and the variety of toppings made each piece a unique treat. Both paellas we ordered were excellent. The seafood and the Iberian pork paellas had the right mix of smoky and savory, and the rice was cooked to perfection. Each bite was an absolute pleasure. Our meal concluded with light sparkling wine and smooth hot chocolate, even without having ordered dessert. As if this amazing meal was not enough, I was invited back into the kitchen by Norberto, the owner. There I met the chefs who cooked our culinary experience. They were enthusiastic and clearly used to meeting the customers. Norberto and I chatted as if we were old friends. We talked about business, my home state of Massachusetts, and life in Spain. We hadva wonderful night at Casa Benigna, and I will 100% return when I am next in Madrid. I may stop in the city just for another great meal with Norberto and his crew.

review_preview: We made a reservation for our last evening in Madrid, keen to sample as many of the vegan restaurants as possible, and were really glad we did!This is some of the less creative vegan food we found in Madrid, which was frankly very welcome!...
review_full: We made a reservation for our last evening in Madrid, keen to sample as many of the vegan restaurants as possible, and were really glad we did! This is some of the less creative vegan food we found in Madrid, which was frankly very welcome! We shared the aperitif style starter with dips and nuts, look out for the bread-this was particularly tasty, the waiter told us it comes in from a bakery out of town daily-well worthwhile. Then I enjoyed the chilli and my partner had the curry which were both really great. For dessert he had the tiramisu, which was probably the best vegan version we‚Äôve had anywhere, and I had the crumble which is hands down the best vegan dessert in Madrid. All in all some top quality but pretty regular vegan food which went down a storm after some delicious, but also pretty whacky vegan food elsewhere in Madrid (including a lot of raw stuff!) highly recommend. Definitely book-they we‚Äôre turning people away the whole time we ate. A special mention for the really friendly service too-chatty and perfect English spoken.

title_review: Amazing Vegan GF Food, Drinks and Service
review_preview: Vega is a fantastic chilled out restaurant and bar close to transport links in Madrid.If you are gluten free or vegan this place is a great place to eat.I visited Vega twice during a recent trip to Madrid and could not praise the...
review_full: Vega is a fantastic chilled out restaurant and bar close to transport links in Madrid. If you are gluten free or vegan this place is a great place to eat. I visited Vega twice during a recent trip to Madrid and could not praise the food and service highly enough. The portions are really generous and really well priced considering the quality of the food.  During a lunch date, my partner and I shared a salad and chickpea stew, both were gorgeous. Very flavorsome and filling without being over facing.  We ended up visiting the restaurant in the evening without making a reservation (I would definitely make a reservation in the future) and the staff set us up at the bar. We shared the 'seafood' (asparagus and rice cooked with nori) and roast vegetables. It was absolutely beautiful, very clean, fresh and flavorsome. After the meal Vega were even kind enough to package up two vegan desserts for us to take home.

title_review: So good my girlfriend nearly replaced me for their caponata!
review_preview: My Italian girlfriend and I visited this place after eating too much greasy and oily Spanish food during our short break.  Being Italian she is really really really picky when it comes to food and especially Italian food.  We went to Il Pizzaiolo after reading...
review_full: My Italian girlfriend and I visited this place after eating too much greasy and oily Spanish food during our short break. Being Italian she is really really really picky when it comes to food and especially Italian food. We went to Il Pizzaiolo after reading good reviews on TA, we concur, this place is one of the nicest places with the tastiest menus we have visited. The decor was great and the atmosphere homely. Their caponata served in a dish made of pizza bread was so good that I was almost replaced. But as I was paying the bill she decided to keep me. My choice of pizza diavola with anchovies raised some eyebrows but it was fantastic. Overall, we would heartily recommend this place. Get their early to avoid the queue.

review_full: Got inside the restaurant because of the rain. Once inside, I liked the look and thought what the hell, let¬¥s eat some Italian food. Then I realized that it was own by Italians, the employees were all speaking Italian, I liked that. I only ordered a pizza because I was on my own. It was delicious!!! If you like very thin pizzas with a touch of basil this is your place. Then I was asked for coffee, I said no and the waiter said well, it is your loss...then I thought, it has to be good because it is made by Italians so I ordered a Cappuccino. Well...I have to say that it was the best coffee I had in years!! The waiter said that he could make an even better one next time for me. Unfortunately, I could not come back but I will for sure If I am in Madrid again. Thanks Danielle (the waiter).

title_review: Over 25 years Experience: Its About Family & Friends
review_preview: I came here based on recommendation of couple I met while touring outside of Spain. This restaurant is known for their paella, which didn't disappoint. It's a small cute place. The owner is a charming guy who sings quite beautifully and greats you at the...
review_full: I came here based on recommendation of couple I met while touring outside of Spain. This restaurant is known for their paella, which didn't disappoint. It's a small cute place. The owner is a charming guy who sings quite beautifully and greats you at the door. He introduces his mother who is there every day. She actually lives upstairs. He was extremely gracious and gave me a tour of the kitchen. It was immaculate, which of course, I was happy to see. We had the seafood paella and the meat (ribs and ham) paella. Both were really good. I enjoyed the meat paella slightly better as I found the seafood paella slightly oily. One thing to take note of is that they charge you for the accoutrements (bread, olive oil, carrots/celery). I point this out as they were brought to the table like most restaurants do and we assumed they were complimentary. We did not know there was a charge for them until we received our bill. I do have issue with providing something and not telling the customer there is a charge and giving them an option to decline.  I will say all in all it was a great experience. Edward, the waiter, was wonderful, he explained the restaurants history, etc and gave us some after dinner drinks...free of charge!

review_preview: We are visiting Madrid mixing a little pleasure with business.  Having spent the day being a tourist we wanted a nice local restaurant and this restaurant didn't fail.  It was tucked down a couple of back streets and you would have missed it if it...
review_full: We are visiting Madrid mixing a little pleasure with business. Having spent the day being a tourist we wanted a nice local restaurant and this restaurant didn't fail. It was tucked down a couple of back streets and you would have missed it if it hadn't been for the olive trees either side of the large wooden front door. From the moment you entered you were made to feel welcome. The menu was in Spanish but the waiter translated it very well for us. There were three in our party and we chose to have a tapas style starter which consisted of smoked salmon, tomatoes with catfish sauce and a mushroom dish, followed by their signature paella chicken and vegetable and a trio dessert which was to share. My god the flavours were Devine the service wasn't rushed and the staff were fab. The decor was unusually quirky with clothes hanging from the ceiling and pots on the walls. Believe the reviews that warn you not to be concerned by location or facade. Indeed you knock on the front door and enter a family's restaurant that is warm and inviting. The chef owner's mother sits at a small table just inside greeting all new guests, makes a walk around the tables to ensure you are happy and then bids you farewell on the way out. Then there's the paella! Incredible with the crusty crispy bottom and garlic aioli and fresh lemon condiments which light up the meal! Service is kind and warm. The decor is so special like someone converted their apartment into a restaurant. Perfect evening!

title_review: The Best Paella and Intimate Service in Madrid.
review_preview: A summary of the visit can be best explained by something Eduano, our host, said to us. He said, you are family here and always welcome back... and we will be back. I would visit Madrid again just to have another meal as Casa Benigna....
review_full: A summary of the visit can be best explained by something Eduano, our host, said to us. He said, you are family here and always welcome back... and we will be back. I would visit Madrid again just to have another meal as Casa Benigna. Unfortunately the owner and master chef was away on other business as we read in Fodor's about his welcoming and charming personality. However on a special note we were able to meet his mother which was really a very special treat for us. We love and cherish moments where owners, their employees and family members make a real genuine show of their devotion to their craft. , The owner, Don Norberro's charm and personality has been immersed by his entire staff. Eduano made the evening one of our best ever as he explained the mastery behind the restaurant, and showed us the many winning awards and certifications that their owner has been given. He explained the magic behind their fabulous Paella; and displayed the quality ingredients that they use. They spare no expense from the custom made dinner wares, to the charmingly decorated interior with whites and blues. They only have 8 to 10 tables so, make a reservation in advance; we did so through our hotel Gran Melia Fenix the day before. Hands down this is the best food we have had in Spain, and we've been here for two weeks and have been using Fodor's, trip adviser and local concierges for research. YOU HAVE TO GET THE PAELLA - it is incredible. Of special note - we took a taxi to the restaurant and when we turned up the street it was a little sketchy and we we're early (830 pm) which is early for dinner in Spain. Most people eat out starting at 10 pm. It is required to knock on the door, and they will answer it, like you're calling on a friend or family member... it's truly charming and sets the tone for the entire evening. I could go on and on about the small details but trust us, if your're a foodie and derive great pleasure from award winning service and pleasurable delectable ingredients, than this is a MUST for you. Please tell Eduano Nick and Amber from San Francisco say hi, and we hope to be back soon.

title_review: Rice elevated!! Forget about any PAELLA you've ever had
review_preview: This place won't find you, but you don't want to miss it either. It's in a mostly residential neighborhood 15 mins away from central Madrid. We took a cab for 12 euro.From the outside you wouldn't even peek in, we thought we were lost!...
review_full: This place won't find you, but you don't want to miss it either. It's in a mostly residential neighborhood 15 mins away from central Madrid. We took a cab for 12 euro. From the outside you wouldn't even peek in, we thought we were lost! But were we in the right place!!  It's a family owned/ran small restaurant (7-8 tables), a mother (the nicest gramma ever) and son (Norberto, super innovative chef/ musician/great conversationist, olive oil connoisseur)'s business, and their specialty is rice presented in quite a few different ways. Their menu is unique and delicious. The whole experience, from the warm welcoming (as if we were family), to the beautiful room, to the service which is generous and attentive, to the "surprises" that await you throught out the dinner. I don't want to spoil the experience, but it is worth evey dime. Remember dinner in Spain is late, say 9pm onwards. You will need reservations.

review_full: I was in Madrid for a recruitment event and someone told me about the Casa Benigna. My mom and used Google maps to find the place and walked there from our hotel which was only 10 minutes. The restaurant is on a side street and is a hidden gem. The waitress was very helpful as we did not speak any Spanish so she translated the entire menu for us. We started out with bread and olive oil. Then, we had the salmon and vegetables. Next we had our main dish which was the la huerta (chicken) patella and it was great. I didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. The chicken and vegetables were baked into the rice. My red wine went perfectly with the dish. Lastly, we had the butter cookies with chocolate sauce and it was a good way to end our experience. We took a picture with the owner's mother and she was very nice. The resatuarant has great ambiance.

review_preview: Solo dinner mid-evening on a business trip. Busy little restaurant, tables close together, quite noisy. Friendly service, with enough English to be helpful when asking for veggie options. They have a menu in English. I asked if the bruschetta was veggie-friendly - by default no...
review_full: Solo dinner mid-evening on a business trip. Busy little restaurant, tables close together, quite noisy. Friendly service, with enough English to be helpful when asking for veggie options. They have a menu in English. I asked if the bruschetta was veggie-friendly - by default no (this is Spain - ham comes with everything, I think it's the law) but the waitress suggested they do "traditional" bruschetta for me. It was possibly the freshest and best I've ever had - just grilled bread, juicy tomatoes, vast quantities of garlic (which I love) and a peppery green olive oil. Simple but superb. My "pizza vegetariano" was, by comparison, only on the good side of average - perfectly acceptable quality for the price but I've had better. The house red was quite quaffable and good value at ‚Ç¨2.50 for a decent size glass. Tiramisu was really pretty good and the free shot of limoncello was a nice way to round off. I'll definitely eat here again the next time I'm in Madrid.

title_review: Lovely perfect find and yummy relaxing lunch
review_preview: We were looking for a simple, not-too-pricey place to grab a quick lunch near the Prado and just stumbled across Tinto y Tapas on our way to a Spanish chain restaurant. So glad we did! It's the perfect European-style lunch joint (although I'm sure it...
review_full: We were looking for a simple, not-too-pricey place to grab a quick lunch near the Prado and just stumbled across Tinto y Tapas on our way to a Spanish chain restaurant. So glad we did! It's the perfect European-style lunch joint (although I'm sure it would be nice and cozy for dinner too) where you can just point and choose off the menu or from the selection of tempting empanadas on display. It is a proper small casual restaurant with nice setting and table service though and not a deli, which just makes for a more relaxing experience. We ended up getting a full meal with glasses of beer and house wine (olives were served with the aperitif), empanadas for starters, a big salad (the best I had in Spain in terms of taste and ingredients) and cold cuts platter and then we ended up picking out another empanada - not because we were still hungry but because they were really good and flavourful. I would actually describe them as what you would get if you took the best elements of a pie, quiche and empanada and then came up with different flavour combinations. I don't remember if we got dessert or not but definitely had coffee and the owner/waiter even offered us a little digestif to go with it. It seems to be run by youngish owners and the service was great. Prices are those of a big city but reasonable enough. We would definitely go back, maybe even for dinner because we liked the atmosphere as well as food.

review_preview: Was in Madrid for 5 days with my son, and we found this place through TripAdvisor while looking for a place to eat after visiting Museo la regna Sofia. We wouldn't have found it otherwise, it's located in a narrow alley, a bit out of...
review_full: Was in Madrid for 5 days with my son, and we found this place through TripAdvisor while looking for a place to eat after visiting Museo la regna Sofia. We wouldn't have found it otherwise, it's located in a narrow alley, a bit out of the main road, although just a few minutes walk from the museum. It was tiny and crowded and we got a small table in a corner seated on barstools, but pleased to even get a table. It was a small place, but with a lovely atmosphere, clean and beautifully decorated. Got the menu, and complementary olives after a minute. Everything sounded good, but we landed on trying empanadas (a tiny savoury pai) manchego cheese, and provolone (witch turned out to be melted cheese with tomatoes and onion) Had we been able to eat more, the small pizzas looked great, and so did the salads. Everything looked good, really. The food was excellent. My son greatly favoured the provolone, that was served with toasted bread sprinkled with olive oil and dried herbs. I favoured the manchego cheese also sprinkled with herbs, and accompanied by a glass of red. The pais melted in our mouths. It was delicious. The staff was attentive, and smiling although very busy with a full set of guests. We couldn't stop smiling, thoroughly enjoying every aspect of the experience. I could go back to Madrid just to eat here again! And the cherry on top? La Nota was less then ‚Ç¨25 for the whole thing.

title_review: Delightful ambience, intriguing introduction, but ultimately disappointing food
review_preview: Casa Benigna is hidden away on the most unprepossessing back street near Parque Berlin and even when you glimpse through the front door, you're unsure what awaits you inside. It's cosy, homely - in fact it feels like the conversion of an intellectual family's front...
review_full: Casa Benigna is hidden away on the most unprepossessing back street near Parque Berlin and even when you glimpse through the front door, you're unsure what awaits you inside. It's cosy, homely - in fact it feels like the conversion of an intellectual family's front room - that's to say a sitting room lined with books and photos, now dotted with dining tables and chairs. The waitress speaks good English - always an unexpected bonus in Madrid - although the menu is in Spanish (which I mention for visitors, we do speak it!).  The owner appears and talks at length about his philosophy of cooking, the family and his mother, and how he latched onto 'patella' - his take on paella - and makes his recommendations. But despite promoting his raw mushroom slices in young balsamic oil and tomato slices with ham, we can't help thinking both starter dishes are bland. The main course of patella de marinera, when it comes, is proudly presented at 90 degrees to the horizontal. Sorry, but if my food is hung at that angle I expect it to slide onto the floor, not stick to the pan. And so it proves, that the house style is to cook it to burnt, removing all trace of the valencian saffron that we had proudly been shown half an hour earlier. As for the marinera, a few small pieces of squid or similar dot the otherwise overly cooked rice.  After two rounds of disappointment, the surprise was the desert, a fresh and tasty strawberry sorbet and delightful chocolate sauce. But by then it was too late. I'm not Spanish so I may have missed something, given the other positive reviews here. But I've had much better, juicier paella elsewhere and for the price, and despite a lovely atmosphere, I won't be going back.

review_preview: This wonderful little gem was our favorite dinner during 8 days in Spain. It is a quaint little spot a few blocks off one of the main roads and delivered on the highest of levels. The empanadas were some of the best we have EVER...
review_full: This wonderful little gem was our favorite dinner during 8 days in Spain. It is a quaint little spot a few blocks off one of the main roads and delivered on the highest of levels. We also ordered their Pizza of the Day which had chorizo, fresh veggies and herbs. Not to mention the excellent wine selection at a great price. We indulged for 2 people and our final bill was under $50 euro. The environment was very lively for a little place--everyone having a good time and the servers worked hard to please everyone. My glass was never empty!

review_full: Looking for a hidden gem full of authentic food and the best Paella in Madrid? Look no further, Casa Benigna is for you! We were immediately greeted with a warm welcome and picked our own table. They gave us a tour of the kitchen and introduced us to the chefs and even let us take pictures with them! The entire staff was very attentive and polite. As non Spanish speaking guests, our waitress recommended the appetizers, main course, and wine which were absolutely amazing and well paired. The chef gave us complementary soup, spare rib delicacy, and dessert. I suggest ordering the smoked salmon appetizer, and at least 2 paella dishes. I highly recommend eating here if you are looking for true authentic food in Madrid with great service and atmosphere.

title_review: I would go every time I am in Madrid
review_preview: This is the best-kept secret in Madrid. The owner has travel the world to know about rice, and how to prepare it. He has devised his own pan, made out of copper and covered in nickel (so is safe to cook on). Because of the...
review_full: This is the best-kept secret in Madrid. The owner has travel the world to know about rice, and how to prepare it. He has devised his own pan, made out of copper and covered in nickel (so is safe to cook on). Because of the very specific way paella is done in Spain, and he uses a different technique, he calls his patella. Norberto and his mother run the place, which has a lovely atmosphere. I went with colleagues on a Saturday for lunch. We were 10, we sat in the ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù which is a separate room for big groups like ours. W ordered 2 assorted entrees (salmon, tomatoes, veggies) and 2 patellas. One seafood, the other one chicken and veggies. Rice was cooked perfectly, and crunchy on the side, which I absolutely loved it!! He explained that in order to cook evenly the rice, one should not use big pieces of meats or veggies, and that in the end; the star of the plate (for him) is the rice. For dessert we order 2 of each they have available so we could all try everything. The one I liked the most was the strawberry sorbet served with balsamic vinegar!! AMAIZING. Wine selection was nice. After all this, they as compliment on the house they served us tejas (very thing cookies with almonds) and chocolate ganache, and the pousse-caf√© they offered 3 different liquors from Galicia. I had the green apple, and it was delicious. They smoke their rice, they do their own olive oil and balsamic vinegar. And all is sold in the restaurant. I brought home the oil and the vinegar, it is worth it. It is pricy, but it is very good! No regrets.

title_review: Way too expensive for what you get
review_preview: Casa Benigna is located in a working class neighbourhood of Madrid. Therefore, once you walk in, you are surprised by the Mediterranean decor (which you would not expect there). The owner of the restaurant is very friendly indeed. All the waiters are Asian (Philippines?), and...
review_full: Casa Benigna is located in a working class neighbourhood of Madrid. Therefore, once you walk in, you are surprised by the Mediterranean decor (which you would not expect there). The owner of the restaurant is very friendly indeed. All the waiters are Asian (Philippines?), and speak poor Spanish and English, which does not help to receive a good service. The size of the portions is very small for the tremendously high prices that you are charged for them. In addition, the food was nothing exceptional (I have eaten much better rice dishes in much, much cheaper restaurants), and, in fact, some of the dishes were too salty (we could barely eat them). Would I recommend this restaurant? Probably no. It seems more a tourist trap than a place where to go to enjoy a relaxed dinner.

title_review: An amazing experience and great food!
review_preview: I've been to Charrua several times and can say it's one of the best restaurants in Madrid both for its food and experience. While it's obviously known for its amazing steak, the whole menu is great, from the vegetables to the truffle fries. The wine...
review_full: I've been to Charrua several times and can say it's one of the best restaurants in Madrid both for its food and experience. While it's obviously known for its amazing steak, the whole menu is great, from the vegetables to the truffle fries. The wine selection is also fantastic.  What makes it stand out is the ambience and the design; the owners have painstakingly designed the interior to resemble an Argentinean/Uruguayan ranch house, and you notice from the second you walk in and smell the wood burning. The jazz and laidback music paired with the amazing lighting (candles and otherwise) create a wonderful ambience that can be enjoyed either as a date or as a long night with a big group. Highest possible recommendation!

review_preview: This restaurant is a hidden gem!  It's tucked away in a neighborhood of locals.  Very small, mabye 5-6 tables.  They do take reservations and I highly recommend making one. The chef is British and his food reflects a mix of English and Spanish style dishes....
review_full: This restaurant is a hidden gem! It's tucked away in a neighborhood of locals. Very small, mabye 5-6 tables. They do take reservations and I highly recommend making one. The chef is British and his food reflects a mix of English and Spanish style dishes. The potato skins and salmon cakes were delicious as was the baked cheese with garlic. The chef personally wants every table to enjoy the food and was very helpful in translating the Spanish-only menu. Highly recommended if you're looking for something different in Madrid!

It cost us 18 euros for that and what amazing value it is.

review_preview: Just to note this place is called Pizzi & Dixie. If you want vegan pizza you won't be disappointed.  They have cracked a good pizza base, but pizza with vegan cheese is pizza with vegan cheese.  There will always be issues of taste and texture....
review_full: Just to note this place is called Pizzi & Dixie. If you want vegan pizza you won't be disappointed. They have cracked a good pizza base, but pizza with vegan cheese is pizza with vegan cheese. There will always be issues of taste and texture. I am fine with both and the three stars are bases on that. Had my vegetarian daughter believed the revelations mentioned in some reviews she would have been sorely disappointed. This is okay pizza with vegan cheese. My daughter's mushroom risotto was not a sublime creamy blend of mixed mushrooms and truffle, it was very ordinary. Vegan risotto can be done much better than this. I got the impression of ingredients being assembled but not being combined with any finesse. The deserts were, quite frankly, an abomination. The lemon pie looked like lemon meringue pie, but it lacked all the taste and texture of a non-vegan version; the Ferreo Rocher cake was dry and further spoilt by a thick, strong and overly-sweet topping. Given other experiences of imaginative vegan cuisine in Madrid this was a poor experience.

review_preview: Another 2-star Michelin restaurant.  It was worth the price as they delivered.  We had ordered a bottle of Yamada Nishiki sake, which was good for the hot summer when it served cold.  We had also ordered Sashimi Moriawase (varied sashimi), Tartar de Atun (tuna, spring...
review_full: Another 2-star Michelin restaurant. It was worth the price as they delivered. We had ordered a bottle of Yamada Nishiki sake, which was good for the hot summer when it served cold. We had also ordered Sashimi Moriawase (varied sashimi), Tartar de Atun (tuna, spring onion and free-range egg). Both were very fresh and tasty. We also had Usuzukuri de Carabinero (finely cut red king prawn with its head juice) and Sashimi de Pescado Blanco (seabass sashimi) which were both very good. We ended with ice cream and creamy and jelly yuzu to refresh our taste bud.

You first pic what type of meat you want for your hotdog (brat, frankfurter, Chicago-style, etc), then you have a list of styles of hotdog with their topics listed. There are options to dress your French fries and they have a couple of nice options for the dessert. My friend and I did the men√∫ del d√≠a each, which includes a hotdog, fries, drink, fries, and a dessert or coffee for only 9,50‚Ç¨ each. I got the Reforma dog with brat meat - it was AMAZING! Really recommend. My friend got the Miami Herald dog and was also really satisfied with it. We both got the oblea for dessert, which is like a very thin wafer with dulce de leche (a caramel-milk spread). We were both really satisfied! If you‚Äôre in the mood for a very good, gourmet-quality hotdog, be sure to check this place out!

review_preview: We've eaten at some of the best sushi restaurants in NYC and LA and I think this was on par with the best, great mix of excellent classic nigiri and sashimi but also had some very good "Kabuki" nigiri, interesting Spanish/European-Japanese fusion (reminded me of...
review_full: We've eaten at some of the best sushi restaurants in NYC and LA and I think this was on par with the best, great mix of excellent classic nigiri and sashimi but also had some very good "Kabuki" nigiri, interesting Spanish/European-Japanese fusion (reminded me of O Ya in NYC). We didn't try any of the hot "classic Japanese" selections but these also looked good from what we saw at neighboring tables. This restaurant is definitely deserving of their Michelin star. Prices are high for Madrid but lower than what would be payed in NYC or LA for a similar meal. Overall would definitely recommend for any sushi lover. We reserved a table around a week in advance. We went here on a Wednesday night around 9:30p, was initially very empty but by 10:30p the place was full (we are still not quite on the Spanish meal schedule I guess). Started with a salmon and tuna sashimi and sushi platter (8 nigiri and toro roll) which were both very good. Then proceeded on to 5 orders (2 pieces each) of the "Kabuki" nigiri including quail egg with pate, beef tar-tar with jalepeno, toro with caramelized sugar, white fish with pine nuts; all were very good with interesting, unique flavors. They also had a good sake and wine selection. Finally, my wife has celiac disease and they were able to accommodate with a large amount of the menu being gluten free (as most sushi is), including many of the "Kabuki" nigiri.

With two small beers our bill came to 232 Euros. Highway robbery by any standard.

I was alone and asked if I could sit in the window, they told me know as they were reserved, so I sat in the middle and ordered my food. They serve in weight and so 200g of prawns was the recommendation. As it wasn't on the menu, I wasn't aware of the price. It came out very quickly and they gave me a piece of bread, as requested. It was delicious. Exactly what I was after. I finished it and drank my water and asked for the bill. At 40 Euros for 12 prawns and a litre of water, I felt this was expensive. BUT it was what I was looking for, so it was ok. My biggest issue was that out of the 8 tables in the window that were empty when I arrived, only one was occupied when I left.  That was disappointing. I like to people watch and as a 'lone diner', it would have been better to sit in the window. Nevermind. Expensive, delicious but not that great with customer service

We started with the "Aros de Cebolla" (onion rings)..."to die for"...kind of a tempura batter covering crispy sweet onion. Their draft beer is excellent as well... as for the main course (the burger of course!) I did choose the fantastic "queso de cabra com cebolla caramelizada y salsa de frutos rojos (goat cheese with caramelised onion and berries sauce)... as them to cook it "PUNTO MENOS"... kind of rare but not bloody! Just perfect! If you are in Madrid, you can't miss this treat... but make a reservation... you can use their facebook page to reserve!

It's always difficult to find a restaurant in Spain open on Nochebuena, which traditionally is a time for to be with the family, so we were pleased to be able to make a reservation, even if we did have to pay a small deposit in advance. We arrived at 21:00 and left just before midnight, having been made very welcome and feeling we were among friends. Because of the day it was a set eleven course meal, but excellent value for money. The food was of a high quality and the drinks wholly acceptable. The owner, Esteban was very much in evidence, helping to serve and clear, so really hands on. We will be eating there again.

review_full: After a bit of research we booked to come here for our high-end meal as part of a weekend in Madrid. From the moment we walked in, everything was great. It's a beautiful restaurant - getting there "early" (i.e. 9pm) meant that we had a choice of tables, which was nice so that we could have a view of the cooking area without being too close (which would be very hot). All the food we had (artichokes, chorizo sausage (South American style), rib-eye steak, sweet potato and courgettes) were prepared beautifully. They had some nice wines both by the bottle and by the glass - one of the Ribera's we had was extremely good. The front of house was very friendly and spoke good English. Overall, highly recommended.

title_review: A real asset in sea food
review_preview: Carta Marina is one those few reastaurant that never disappoint the guest.Tables are quite far from each other and you can talk without your neightbore listen what you say , seat are confortable , the place is clean , no kitchen smell.The personel...
review_full: Carta Marina is one those few reastaurant that never disappoint the guest. Tables are quite far from each other and you can talk without your neightbore listen what you say , seat are confortable , the place is clean , no kitchen smell. The personel is very attentive and professional and service is fast if considering that all is done expressely. What is however surprising is the quality of the material used and the perfect cooking of sead food they are serving. Shell , prawn even the rare Perceves are always available at the best of their performance. We were 6 and we have tasted more than 10 different plates , all perfect , one after the other in timely continuity , all warm and juicy. My guests were so happy and frankly very seldom you can dine at this global level having variety of sea food and fish. we had 4 bottle of champagne and with a big fish as main course plus dessert the bill was Euro 750. If instead of french vine we had some good spanish the bill would have been sustantially lower. Definitely we can dine in Madrid for lower price of somewhere else more cool but for a dinner at that level I challenge anybody to find a better place. Carta Marina is a must for sea food in Madrid a real Asset !!

title_review: I would go again when visiting Madrid
review_preview: We loved this restaurant, which we visited one weekday afternoon. The menus is a bit unusual from the standard sushi restaurant in Madrid or elsewhere in Span but this is not a negative comment. Listen carefully about the specials of the day, as they are...
review_full: We loved this restaurant, which we visited one weekday afternoon. The menus is a bit unusual from the standard sushi restaurant in Madrid or elsewhere in Span but this is not a negative comment. Listen carefully about the specials of the day, as they are likely to be exceptional. On the day of our visit the specials included razor clams and cockles. They were both done to perfection! We also allowed the chef to choose our nigiris and we were not disappointed! There were all excellent, even the ‚Äòstandard‚Äô salmon and tuna; the exceptional one was the mackerel. I am not usually a fan of mackerel but this was done wonderfully. There are also some unusual items on the menu, worth exploring; we tried the bone marrow which was served with Japanese seaweed bread. Not a usual item but wonderful nevertheless.  The restaurant is stylish and the service exceptional. The wine list is excellent and if you want to finish with something sweet they have desert wine choices which are not on the list. We finished with the chocolate selection, which was not very Japanese but the perfect end to our meal.  The restaurant is not cheap, but the prices are appropriate for what it offers. Highly recommended.

review_preview: At the suggestion of a friend we went for lunch at Jauja, and we were happy with the choice: a funky atmosphere, great service and the choices were very tasty.Yes, the prices are a bit on the steep side compared to other nearby locations,...
review_full: At the suggestion of a friend we went for lunch at Jauja, and we were happy with the choice: a funky atmosphere, great service and the choices were very tasty. Yes, the prices are a bit on the steep side compared to other nearby locations, but the quality of the food is very good: the "Vitello Tonnato" was really very good -not too many places get it right. The Burrata was also very good. Jauja is also good with children - our very picky 6 year old managed to eat very well. In short, we had a very good lunch and service was great. It was worth the price, and we will be back.

title_review: Reliable, elegant but friendly, lovely covered terrace
review_preview: We had a very pleasant evening with Madrileno friends.  Set on a small plazuela on the side of Principe Velazquez. it has a very elegant and large enclosed standalone terrace and surprisingly large, cosy spaces inside. Very friendly and efficient staff who manage the curfew...
review_full: We had a very pleasant evening with Madrileno friends. Set on a small plazuela on the side of Principe Velazquez. it has a very elegant and large enclosed standalone terrace and surprisingly large, cosy spaces inside. Very friendly and efficient staff who manage the curfew restrictions smoothly - you really only feel it at the moment they have to close. Traditional, dependable food. We shared some well prepared but not very exciting plates chosen by our friends who were looking for "staples" so we didn't really get to sample the range of cooking. E100 for 4 with 3 glasses of wine and a couple of beers.  It's well known, dependable but not adventurous.

review_preview: This small and cozy restaurant serves a Fusion of Japanese and Spanish dishes, hence the "Japanish" categorization. Both chefs are very well trained and suited to please your palate trough a series of dishes that are simply superb.My only observation: the Oyster was too...
review_full: This small and cozy restaurant serves a Fusion of Japanese and Spanish dishes, hence the "Japanish" categorization. Both chefs are very well trained and suited to please your palate trough a series of dishes that are simply superb. My only observation: the Oyster was too cold and impaires a bit the full potential of the morsel, a couple of degress warmer and it would have been great as all the other dishes were. Make a reservation well in advance, specially if you want to sit by the Sushi counter and chat with Juan and Pablo. The waiters are attentive, respectfull and very knowledgeable of all the ingredients that come into making such the perfect morsel that you take to your mouth with your fingrers. Give the chefs the opportunity to surprise you, specially with the Nigiris. There is one made with prawn that tastes as if you are eating a Spanish Paella, Wonderful! I'm planing to go in two weeks to try desserts, since I was full and very pleased when the time to order desserts came.

review_preview: Terrible booking experiences. I tried to book a reservation online for my bachelorette party, but accidently booked the wrong date, as the calendar was flipped from what I was used to. I canceled it, then had a friend try to rebook, but she did the...
review_full: Terrible booking experiences. I tried to book a reservation online for my bachelorette party, but accidently booked the wrong date, as the calendar was flipped from what I was used to. I canceled it, then had a friend try to rebook, but she did the same thing. We could not cancel the second reservation, as it was under the same name, for the same time, and the system believed it was already cancelled. So we tried going by the restaurant to tell them in-person (I was traveling through and don't speak Spanish, so unable to have cell phone service to call). They were CLOSED when they stated that they would be open. I was unable to tell them to cancel the reservation, as it was closed. I even tried to eat here that night (with my bachelorette party), but they were closed on a day stated open. Then they emailed me about the wrong date reservation. I told them I didn't want it. It was within the free cancellation date (I have this confirmed with their stated policy for a weekday and the email time stamps). They charged my credit card a 75 EU cancellation fee, even though it was prior to the deadline. I tried fighting it with my friend, who speaks Spanish translating, but they will not comply. They last said they are "looking into it", but haven't replied in over a month. TERRIBLE SERVICE AND EXPERIENCE. AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COST.

review_preview: I have eaten at Sol Azteca several times (solo, with my girlfriend, with friends), and it consistently delivers, regardless of what I have eaten.You can tell the food is homemade (except perhaps the totopos they serve you as a tapa of sorts). The tortillas...
review_full: I have eaten at Sol Azteca several times (solo, with my girlfriend, with friends), and it consistently delivers, regardless of what I have eaten. You can tell the food is homemade (except perhaps the totopos they serve you as a tapa of sorts). The tortillas are always of point, and you have multiple options of them. There are possibilities to order big platters with tacos stuffed with different types of meat (and vegetarian-suitable options, too). The aguja de choriqueso became an instant favorite: a gigantic plate with lots of chorizo, veggies and melted cheese, that will make you go into a happy food coma. The staff are all Mexican, and very friendly, very close, checking up on you every once in a while, explaining the details of each dish, and willing to answer further questions if you ask them, happy to share the knowledge of Mexican gastronomy with you. Would absolutely recommend for anyone.

Food was great and atmosphere was great. We do recommend one make reservations. They pack up with locals. Highly recommend. And would definitely return.

review_preview: I don't think I've ever been more excited to write a review for a restaurant. But if I could, I would give Nina Pasta bar all the stars! The restaurant is on a nice small street, so while wandering the area we just happened to...
review_full: I don't think I've ever been more excited to write a review for a restaurant. But if I could, I would give Nina Pasta bar all the stars! The restaurant is on a nice small street, so while wandering the area we just happened to stumble upon it on our first day in Madrid. When I saw that it was authentic pasta, I figured it would be great to give it a try, and I'm so glad that we did. We went on a Sunday, the same day as El Rastro, huge weekly flea market in the La Latina neighborhood. The streets were packed and so was Nina. However, we snagged a large community table in the back. One important tip about going on Sunday- they have a limited menu due to the amount of people coming because of El Rastro. The menu offers 2-3 tapas, and only 2 lunch options. But don't worry because both options are AMAZING. Their carbonara and Gnocci are to die for! We also had tinto de Verano to drink (sangria) that was also really yummy.  We loved this place so much that on our last full day we had to return for one more meal! We went on a Tuesday afternoon for lunch, perfect time because it wasn't crowded and they also had their full menu available. We were happy to be greeted by the same lovely servers who remembered us from Sunday. My fianc√© went with the carbonara again and I tried one of their daily specials, and OMG I am so glad so did. They offered a pappardelle black truffle and parmesan pasta and it was life changing to say the least. I spent time thinking about how I can bring some back to the US. I also tried to savor each bite by eating very slowly lol. During that meal we also had the gnocchi bravas, their take on the classic patatas bravas. That also was amazing, and a nice change since we'd been eating the traditional bravos all week. Please, please, please if you're in Madrid stop by Ninas Pasta Bar for lunch. You will not regret it and you probably will think about the pasta for the rest of your trip, like I did!!

title_review: If only I could give 10 stars!
review_preview: We happened upon this busy lane after walking around trying to find somewhere to eat and we are so pleased to have found this place. We had to wait for a table but the bubbly and friendly waitress (granddaughter of the restaurants name sake), openly...
review_full: We happened upon this busy lane after walking around trying to find somewhere to eat and we are so pleased to have found this place. We had to wait for a table but the bubbly and friendly waitress (granddaughter of the restaurants name sake), openly explained how close some of the tables were to finishing their meals so we only waited 5 minutes. We started with the Gnocci Bravos which was amazing! I don‚Äôt think we will ever go back to Patatas Bravas after eating this dish. We then had the Capote Ragout, the Ravioli Bufalina and both were absolutely perfect. The waitress explained that much of the cooking is based on her grandmothers recipes and she said all the food is cooked with love. We were made feel very welcome at this restaurant, our meals were just perfect and the service provided was excellent. I highly recommend finding this place if your in Madrid and looking for a great meal:)

review_preview: After a few disappointing tapas 'experiences' south of Plaza Mayor, we chose this place based on the location (close to our hotel), their website and some excellent Tripadvisor reviews.  We were too late to book for Saturday night, so went for Sunday lunchtime (from 13h00)...
review_full: After a few disappointing tapas 'experiences' south of Plaza Mayor, we chose this place based on the location (close to our hotel), their website and some excellent Tripadvisor reviews. We were too late to book for Saturday night, so went for Sunday lunchtime (from 13h00) instead. First thing to say is that Abaceria Tapas Lambuzo looks like nothing at all from the outside (nondescript street, small doorway, no tables outside). You would walk past it without a second glance, but trust me, it's great. The place is small, and to be honest, not the most comfortable restaurant in the world, but with a great atmosphere, delightful staff and really good food from Cadiz in southern Spain. The front of the restaurant is basically for 'bar tapas' and the crowd spills out onto the street; the restaurant is to the rear. Unlike many comparable places, the menu (English translation available) is fairly short, but everything we had (potato salad with tuna, anchovies, pork cheeks, clams in sherry, almond cake, cheese with honey) was delicious, well-presented and good value for money. Most dishes come as either a full or a half raciones (or tapa size if you are at the bar) so you can sample several things without over-facing your stomach or your wallet. Wine list is straightforward and accessible. Service is friendly and efficient (it has to be, the place is rammed!) A restaurant with real heart.

review_preview: I had planned to eat at La Plater√≠a but the place was full. A little further up the road I found this hole-in-the-wall place.As you may have guessed from the name, they serve crepes. There are savoury cr√™pes and sweet ones.This place, like...
review_full: I had planned to eat at La Plater√≠a but the place was full. A little further up the road I found this hole-in-the-wall place. As you may have guessed from the name, they serve crepes. There are savoury cr√™pes and sweet ones. This place, like just about everywhere I have passed today, is packed. I managed to get the last table (I saw people being turned away as I was seated). As I have said, this place isn't big but it is busy. Despite the number of clients in the place, the staff seemed to make time to 'play' with a table of French seniors, laughing and joking with them in French. I ordered a Cr√™pe with cheese, tuna and vegetables. When it arrived, my first thought was "meh" as it didn't look all that inviting. Nor did there seem to be too much of it. I was wrong on both counts. Whilst it wasn't particularly thick, there was a layer of melted Emmental cheese running through it which made it quite filling. The vegetables were served on top and added a sweetness to the flavour. Sadly I was unable to identify any tuna at all. The dish itself was very filling and I was unable to eat all of it, although, if there had been something to offer a break in a textured I may have been able to. This singularity of texture in a meal seems to be a bit of a running theme in this bit of the world. I saw sweet crepes being served to the table of French oldies. It was done with great flair, especially those that were served flamb√©.  I was much too full to partake. My meal, with a couple of beers, came to 16‚Ç¨. This was a bit of an experience. I'm not too sure I'd do it again although it may be nice to try a sweet Cr√™pe.

review_preview: This small cozy restaurant situated at Calle Huertas, about 5mins walk from meuseo del prado or 8mins walk from Atocha train station. Pretty cramp restaurant and crowded at 3pm. But it's worth the wait! They have English menu and I've asked the waitress to recommend...
review_full: This small cozy restaurant situated at Calle Huertas, about 5mins walk from meuseo del prado or 8mins walk from Atocha train station. Pretty cramp restaurant and crowded at 3pm. But it's worth the wait!  They have English menu and I've asked the waitress to recommend a savory crepe. She recommended the campagnarde (with smoked duck ham, Brie, hot apple and honey). The crepe was made from buck weed flour. The cheese melt nicely and the saltiness of the duck ham mixes well with the sweetness of the apply and honey. Perfect combination!! I took the Cubaine flambee (pineapple, coconut ice creme, caramel, flambee rum). It's a shouting out loud OMG!!! The burnt rum with the coconut ice creme and soft pineapple was heaven!!!  The total price for 2 crepes and a bottle of Aqua was ‚Ç¨ 18.10 Give this a try, not too filling for an afternoon tea and rest from all the walking.

title_review: Food is 5 Stars but owner could be nicer!
review_preview: We actually went to this darling authentic French crepe restaurant twice while visiting Madrid.  Our first experience was 5 stars the whole way through.  We had a darling French waitress and almost no one else in the place.  The crepes, savory and sweet, were amazing....
review_full: We actually went to this darling authentic French crepe restaurant twice while visiting Madrid. Our first experience was 5 stars the whole way through. We had a darling French waitress and almost no one else in the place. The crepes, savory and sweet, were amazing. Two of us returned the following Sunday and every table was full except ours right inside the door. There are only 3 servers (including the owner) so they are super busy but the owner was very short and impatient with my imperfect Spanish and even my English. I would still absolutely recommend and hope you get one of the female servers. The crepes and atmosphere are great!

We may go back at some point to sample the dessert crepes - they looked awfully good!

review_preview: After two meals of tapas, we needed to find an alternative for our kids.  This restaurant was down the street from our apartment.  The fours of use each ordered a different desert crepe (for dinner). They were all delicious and satisfying and as good as...
review_full: After two meals of tapas, we needed to find an alternative for our kids. This restaurant was down the street from our apartment. The fours of use each ordered a different desert crepe (for dinner). They were all delicious and satisfying and as good as the crepes we had in Paris. The restaurant is almost like a little cave with stone walls. The waitress was very friendly.  As an aside, the owner is courteous and friendly. Due to a poor internet connection even though I gave them the credit card, the transaction hung up, so I ended up paying with cash. When we got back to our apartment, our credit card company sent us an email saying that we had been charged an international transaction for the exact amount of the meal. I went back to the restaurant and the waitress called the owner who came in in10 minutes and spoke excellent English, explained that there was no charge and that sometimes the credit card company does this, and to call him the next day if there was an issue. Since we left Madrid at 7 AM the next day, I checked at the end of our trip and the owner was correct, we were not charged by credit card company. I was very impressed that the owner came in to speak with me about the charge.

review_full: What a lucky accident that we spotted this charming creperie after a hot and tiring day sightseeing in Madrid! The interior is cool and inviting and the staff friendly and efficient. There is a huge variety of crepes, both savoury and sweet on the menu and my vegan friend was extremely happy to find lots of tasty dishes to choose from. Our orders arrived promptly, the cider that we ordered was excellent, the atmosphere was relaxed and we were extremely pleased our find. This lovely restaurant is situated on one of the streets leading to the Prado so it's easy to find and definitely worth doing so!

review_preview: According to previous reviews and my personal experience, this is probably the best Italian restaurant in Madrid. The general level in this city is not excellent (compared to London) but the genuine passion of these guys should be rewarded.I went there for an early...
review_full: According to previous reviews and my personal experience, this is probably the best Italian restaurant in Madrid. The general level in this city is not excellent (compared to London) but the genuine passion of these guys should be rewarded. I went there for an early quick dinner at 20.30 (in Madrid, customers would flock around 9pm), no booking.. Waitress turned out to be from Sardinia (where I was born) so it was a pleasant surprise. The impression is that they expect a relaxed meal with many courses taking advantage of the daily advice from the waitress (very fluent in Spanish and clearly quite experienced dealing with customers).  Since my case was slightly different, I asked whether they would provide half portions (to try two different mains) and she said that would depend on the main. Eventually I was happy to order only homemade tagliatelle with mushrooms because I love homemade pasta. They were quite tasty, a little too greasy but it seems a common issue for this type of sauce. I opted for a pastiera as a dessert; it is quite hard to find it as it's less renowned than other desserts and this praises the boldness and the skills of the chef.  The presentation was superb but even the flavour recalled the best patisserie pastiera. Prices are mid-range but it's the right price for the superior quality and you won't run out of options with such large range of starters and mains (besides pizza) listed in the menu. I would recommend at least two visits to make most of this restaurant but if you love Italian food, this is a must in Madrid!

title_review: Excellent food , friendly service by owner Bruno
review_preview: I was walking by the Opera area of Madrid and decided to step into this restaurant, i had a craving for Italian food. I met Bruno, the owner, I had known him way back and had not seen him in ages. He is a Television...
review_full: I was walking by the Opera area of Madrid and decided to step into this restaurant, i had a craving for Italian food. I met Bruno, the owner, I had known him way back and had not seen him in ages. He is a Television and Theater actor that owns and runs the restaurant (I honestly do not know where he gets the time). Bruno come from Rome and knows his food. I was sort of undecided on wahy I wanted so he offered me some home made pasta and meat balls Arrabbiatta (spicy) ... they were so good!!!  Do not be surprised to find actors, singers and TV personalities while dining, since Bruno knows everybody in the biz... On Thursday night they have opereta night so if you feel like singing, take center stage, it is a lot of fun !!! Bottom line go there for the food, it is true Italian, they even have a stone pizza oven brought in from Sicily !!! Great food and friendly professional service. OHHH !!! and do not forget to ask for a tangerine type of "limoncello" !!!

title_review: Best Italian food in Italy - Wait this is Madrid!!
review_preview: Like others that have reviewed this restaurant, we wanted a break from the standard Madrid food and tried Ouh Babbo.  We got there at 8:45 pm but had to come back later as they don't open until 9;00.  Being there, well, early, there was only...
review_full: Like others that have reviewed this restaurant, we wanted a break from the standard Madrid food and tried Ouh Babbo. We got there at 8:45 pm but had to come back later as they don't open until 9;00. Being there, well, early, there was only one other person eating there. We had just come from two weeks in Italy and were delighted with the quality and authenticity of the food. The food, the wine, the service, and the atmosphere were absolutely perfect. We chatted with the owner for about 1/2 hour and were charmed with his honesty and integrity. Don't miss this restaurant or you will hate yourself in the morning!!

review_preview: After being in Spain a few weeks, I'll admit it:  we were a little hammed out.  So it was with great relief we found Ouh, Babbo!, an Italian restaurant tucked away near the Puerta del Sol.  At first we weren't sure if we should try...
review_full: After being in Spain a few weeks, I'll admit it: we were a little hammed out. So it was with great relief we found Ouh, Babbo!, an Italian restaurant tucked away near the Puerta del Sol. At first we weren't sure if we should try it, as the inside decor of red, white, and black was a bit off-putting and had more of an '80s lounge vibe to it. But the food, ooohhh the food, MORE than made up for any lack of design taste.  We were there for one reason: pizza. But quite frankly, we weren't expecting much. After all, this is Spain and if we wanted great pizza then we were on the wrong side of the Mediterranean. Wrong! The pizza was absolutely delicious, from the crust to the sauce to the cheese and ingredients - it was crazy good. As good as any pizza we've eaten in Italy, and that says a lot because we've eaten a silly amount of pizza in Italy. Backing up just a moment (I was so excited to get to the pizza part), we were also presented with a little Italian tapas before our pizza, which was arugula wrapped in a slice of mortadella and drizzled with balsamic vinaigrette. Heaven. And, although we didn't have any pasta dishes, we eyeballed just about everything coming out of the kitchen and the other diners seemed extremely pleased with their pasta selections. Without question, we would heartily recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a delectable, quality Italian meal in Spain. Because man cannot live by tapas alone...

review_full: If you want to attend an Italian comedy show, this is the perfect place to visit. A very nice welcome by the manager who will personally greet you at your table to make you feel special. The only problem is that he will lie through his teeth to sell you his most expensive "fresh and delicious" pasta or pizza. Actually the menu is so long that it takes you 10 minutes to decide what you want to eat. You try to stick to the basics but when the ingredients are not fresh it can only be a disaster. I could tell from the bread alone that I would be taken for a fool. Really unacceptable and nobody, even people who have the worst tastes in food and seem to rate this "restaurant" highly, should have to pay for this.

If you are visiting Madrid there are hundreds of other places with better food and better prices.

title_review: Amazing food and even better service!
review_preview: I arranged a meal here on Saturday for a large group of 28 people (hen party) and with a large proportion of 'foodies' in the group the pressure was on to pick a great restaurant. I needn't have worried though as we were extremely well...
review_full: I arranged a meal here on Saturday for a large group of 28 people (hen party) and with a large proportion of 'foodies' in the group the pressure was on to pick a great restaurant. I needn't have worried though as we were extremely well looked after - the food was exceptional and the service absolutely first class! The owner of the restaurant (aka Robert De Niro) ensured he was at hand to look after our every need - even serenading us with a great operatic performance (order the truffle special to experience this for yourself!) I've eaten at a lot of Italian restaurants over the years but this is hands down one of the best in the world. I'd highly recommend the roasted pumpkin, sage and amaretti crunch ravioli, absolute perfection!

The food was very substandard-lasagne had obviously been reheated-probably in a microwave from the leathery texture. None of the 3 of us finished their main courses. title_review: Buzzing authentic Italian in Madrid's heart
review_preview: A stone's throw from the Teatro real, this is a find - no doubt.  Bruno (the manager / owner), may be over the top (breaking into Italian Opera arias at a turn), but he provides a clearly dedicated service and as a result an excellent...
review_full: A stone's throw from the Teatro real, this is a find - no doubt. Bruno (the manager / owner), may be over the top (breaking into Italian Opera arias at a turn), but he provides a clearly dedicated service and as a result an excellent lunching or dining experience. Great produce, freshly made pasta and sauce combinations. Our dinner started with a fresh baby spinach leaf and pear salad with balsamic glaze and parmesan flakes and a mozzarella salad. This was followed by freshly made spaghetti with a whole poached egg, shaved black truffle and grated parmesan. Decadent ad delicious. House red (Chianti?) and a digestif of Mirto fortified wine from Sardinia (it has the essence of Rosemary). Perfect for a very late supper. The only downer is that it gets busy - book your table ahead or get there early.
