title_review: If in Madrid, it's a must
review_preview: Ok. So it was a Monday evening. Ok. It's not tapas but why weren't there more clients at Ouh....babbo? This resto. is very special. We've been three times in Italy this year and not once have we had an Italian meal as good as this....
review_full: Ok. So it was a Monday evening. Ok. It's not tapas but why weren't there more clients at Ouh....babbo? This resto. is very special. We've been three times in Italy this year and not once have we had an Italian meal as good as this. The melanzane millefeuille was to die for. I had a main with ravioli and mushroom with a beautiful, intense tomato sauce. Then my wife suggested that I cleanse my palate and try her ravioli with pumpkin and amaretto crunch. So wonderfully delicate. For desert I had a canolo. Outside of Sicily I haven't had a canolo that has come anywhere near those you get there and I still haven't, but this was a pretty good effort. Certainly the best I've had outside of Sicily. My wife had a great lemon sorbet. Pricy for Madrid but certainly great value for money. The service was charming and the music,1950's Italian, helped the lack of atmosphere due to few patrons.

The owner was very kind and said he would be very happy to serve us even though the kitchen closed at 4:00 p.m. The four of us enjoyed 2 very good pizzas and two pasta entrees w/truffle. We were starving and very thankful to be served since finding a good restaurant opened at this time of day can be quite a challenge. Portions were very generous and prices reasonable. We were not rushed to finish as the owner explained that he stays in his restaurant during the hours that the kitchen is closed for the afternoon. Thank you Ouh,Babbo! for your gracious hospitality!

title_review: FINEST ITALIAN FOOD IN THE VERY HEART OF MADRID
review_preview: Run by a well-known Spanish-Italian actor, this restaurant has become very popular. It is  close to Opera Metro station, in the very heart of Madrid and has become one of the best italian eateries in Madrid. It offers delicious fresh italian delicacies in a relaxed...
review_full: Run by a well-known Spanish-Italian actor, this restaurant has become very popular. It is close to Opera Metro station, in the very heart of Madrid and has become one of the best italian eateries in Madrid. It offers delicious fresh italian delicacies in a relaxed atmosphere. We shared antipasti: a fresh burrata, and a fine pizza marinara, which was perfect, thin and tasty, then we had a pasta or a risotto each. Which was more than enough. Perfect Pappardelle alle 4 funghi, nice risotto...and I had and scrumptious spaghetti dish seasoned at your table with a raw egg, freshly grated truffle chips and fine Parmesan cheese. Desserts are also good, with wonderful -perhaps too sweet- canoli and the 'pie of the day', this time an apple pie with a cinnamon 'crocanti' topping.Including service, coffes and drinks, we paid 30 euros per person. The owner and a couple of musicians sing 'serenatas' every Thursday night, so if you want to go for a late dinner, book well in advance. Ask for a table in the main dining room. It's small, but it's there where the action is.

review_full: We took some friends here with us Friday night. Greeted with "Okay - no reservations? I must take you to hte inferno." And downstairs to a red and black but comfortable, non-inferno space - that became clear on receiving the menu was the circle of hell reserved for the indecisive. Oh ... the choices. I opted for carpaccio of bresaola and then pici with cacio e pepe - sinple food done well. But my wife had venison carpaccio (ummmm!) and amazing ravioloni with cuttlefish ink flavored pasta filled with salmon, rice and cheese, dressed with a shrimp cream sauce. Wonderful. Our companions were likewise blessed and we sat at table from before ten to after 1 am sharing food and talk and espresso and grappa or limoncello. Attentive, friendly and non-intrusive staff. Polly and I went back for lunch today (Sunday), had a pizza margherita con scamorza (a "Dop Cornelia") and birra Ichnusa from Sardegna. Wish we could move here or he could open in Sacramento.

review_preview: This restaurant was recommended on tripadvisor and was right next to where I was staying. I eat there only once as I wanted to try as many restaurants as possible on my trip. They only serve Crepes but there are many savoury crepe delights and...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended on tripadvisor and was right next to where I was staying. I eat there only once as I wanted to try as many restaurants as possible on my trip. They only serve Crepes but there are many savoury crepe delights and also some lovely sweet crepes for desert. My wife and I had two savoury crepes each and shared one sweet crepe. These were lovely to eat and while I think one savoury crepe would be enough for lunch maybe with a sweet crepe, for dinner you would probably need two savoury crepes to fill you up. We had a bottle of white wine and coffees with our meal and it all came to less than 60 euros. A great dining experience and very good value for money.

title_review: Delicious Food and a Very Good Value
review_preview: Le Comptoir de la Crepe at Calle Huertas, 68 just off Calle Jesus was delightful.  We thoroughly enjoyed the tasty gallettes (buckwheat flour crepes) topped with cheese, mushrooms, and peppers as well as egg, ham, and cheese.  The choice of wines was good and the...
review_full: Le Comptoir de la Crepe at Calle Huertas, 68 just off Calle Jesus was delightful. We thoroughly enjoyed the tasty gallettes (buckwheat flour crepes) topped with cheese, mushrooms, and peppers as well as egg, ham, and cheese. The choice of wines was good and the prices were reasonable. The atmosphere is intimate. The chef enjoys meeting diners and getting first-hand comments about the food. He speaks Spanish, French and English.

title_review: Why crepes in Madrid? Cause they're better than Tapas.
review_preview: I'm a pretty sophisticated traveller, so when I say tapas are horrible in Madrid, you can take my word for it. I think I was just hitting the touristy, lazy tapas places, and not the great ones. But after several terrible meals, I was thrilled...
review_full: I'm a pretty sophisticated traveller, so when I say tapas are horrible in Madrid, you can take my word for it. I think I was just hitting the touristy, lazy tapas places, and not the great ones. But after several terrible meals, I was thrilled to discover Le Comptoir! It's run by a great looking, really charming frenchman and his equally charming wife/girlfriend in a quaint little hole in the wall. This guy did everything himself in a little tiny kitchen but he worked magic. And just so you don't get the wrong idea, these are not little fussy crepes. These are big macho manly crepes with a little substance to them. They are satisfying. Don't let this guy talk to your wife cause she'll fall in love with him. But do take his word on what his best dessert crepe is. I forgot it's name but we had two of them in a row. Two in a row!!! If you knew my wife, you'd know what kind of miracle that crepe has to be to let me have two of them! Oh and this is the first place I experienced Mahou beer on draft. It is heavenly! Remember that name Mahou. You can't get it in Los Angeles except maybe by FedEx and you'll miss it.

review_preview: Not a single problem with this restaurant. Went on the advice of a friend who lives in Madrid. He joined us with his girlfriend so we asked them to choose the food to ensure we had the sort of food they would eat, rather than...
review_full: Not a single problem with this restaurant. Went on the advice of a friend who lives in Madrid. He joined us with his girlfriend so we asked them to choose the food to ensure we had the sort of food they would eat, rather than us picking the food we always pick. We had pulpo a la Gallega (Galician style octopus) and hummus de berenjenas (aubergine based dip) to start. For the mains we had chipirones (squid) and a grilled steak dish. We had other dishes as well, and although I can't remember some of the dishes, it was all, without exception, absolutely excellent. Staff were attentive and friendly and there was also a very good wine list. What more could you want?

title_review: Crepes the size of your face!
review_preview: Myself and two friends were on a tight time limit to eat before our class meeting.  We searched creperies and this one popped up with great reviews so we figured we would check it out.  Le Comptoir was an adorable hole-in-the-wall place that makes you...
review_full: Myself and two friends were on a tight time limit to eat before our class meeting. We searched creperies and this one popped up with great reviews so we figured we would check it out. Le Comptoir was an adorable hole-in-the-wall place that makes you feel like you're sitting in a friend's old-fashion home with a comfortable feel. There was only one guy working who understand English pretty well. With only about 25 minutes to sit, order, eat, pay, and be our own way he insured us that we had plenty of time. Sure enough, our food was out within 5 minutes of ordering. Granted it was decently empty, but he was the only one working, cooking, etc. The crepes tasted so good that we had to come back the next day. This time it was a little later in the evening and every table was full. Yet again, quick service. There were two servers working, and the same guy cooking in the little closet of a kitchen. The food was brought to us within maybe 10 minutes tops of ordering. These may be the best crepes I've had so far and makes me not want to go anywhere else. Between the quick service, amazing taste, tons of selection, and overall ambiance and flow of the place, you are sure to love your visit. I had the vegetarian crepe (pictured) and it was beyond delicious and hit the spot.

review_full: I went to this restaurant out of the blue with a few friends. First stepping in the restaurant, you feel at home. It's a small, cozy kind of hole in the wall place; great time to relax and enjoy a good crepe. I ordered a savory crepe with goat cheese and tomatoes, which was very tasty. My friend and I also split a crepe with butter and sugar, which I preferred over the savory crepe- but they were both delicious! The guy who owns the place is extremely friendly and welcoming- we were on a time crunch and he made sure everything was served quickly. I recommend anyone to stop in for a quick crepe while in Madrid.

We plan to go back for lunch before we leave Madrid. Highly recommend.

title_review: A taste of France near the Prado
review_preview: This was a great little place on a delightful street in Madrid. The crepes are classic Normandy buckwheat, made fresh in minutes as you order. They were absolutely delicious. Proprietor is friendly and fluent in Spanish, French and English--a real help after a day of...
review_full: This was a great little place on a delightful street in Madrid. The crepes are classic Normandy buckwheat, made fresh in minutes as you order. They were absolutely delicious. Proprietor is friendly and fluent in Spanish, French and English--a real help after a day of struggling with the language. The perfect place to stop just a couple blocks away from the Prado. NOT a tourist trap!

review_preview: So impressed by this restaurant. It started in the Canary Islands and now has an outpost in Madrid run by one of the cousins Jose. I am a flight attendant and 5 of us went early (8:45pm) without a reservation on a Friday night. Every...
review_full: So impressed by this restaurant. It started in the Canary Islands and now has an outpost in Madrid run by one of the cousins Jose. I am a flight attendant and 5 of us went early (8:45pm) without a reservation on a Friday night. Every table was reserved (they are booked full almost every night so make a reservation), but they graciously seated us with the promise that we would be finished by 10:15 (when the next guests had the table). We got the recommendation from a pax on our flight who is friends with the staff. We truly were treated like Royalty! Abel our waiter is the best! Amazing food at very reasonable prices. I had the Tuna (light dish and perfectly seared with an amazing sauce), the Baccalao was cooked perfectly, and the pork dish was succulent. We also ordered the Beef noodle dish which was very rich and delicious (but might need a bit more beef according to my friend). All in all, I strongly recommend this restaurant. Only downside, they do not have English menus which wasn't a problem for our group as I speak the language and Abel also speaks English. Enjoy!

review_preview: So we were down to the last days of a 3 week holiday touring southern Spain, ending in Madrid. Getting tired of Spanish fare, we were longing for anything besides tapas with fries. We found Ouh Babbo, a small Italian Bistro, just up the hill...
review_full: So we were down to the last days of a 3 week holiday touring southern Spain, ending in Madrid. Getting tired of Spanish fare, we were longing for anything besides tapas with fries. We found Ouh Babbo, a small Italian Bistro, just up the hill from the Opera. Ate dinner there twice, fettuccine with mushrooms knocked our socks off along with a beet salad to share. It was a Thurs night when locals joined the Italian owners and his band for an hour of terrific music. Bruno later told us he played a lead in Momma Mia. It showed, the boy could sing! We made a point to have our last meal of the trip back there. This time we ordered Bruno's special pasta. A spaghetti type noodle done in butter, topped with poached egg. At the table thin slices of dark truffle and parmesiano were grated on top. Oh my, fabulous. Try their desserts, I loved the chocolate moose with passion fruit. Highly recommended.

review_preview: The food is excellent; the service is very good; the price is fair; and the experience is noteworthy but the name connotes nothing in English (means 'dad' in Italian).  Recommended by the excellent hotel (Preciados), so we ventured in.  Very close by but with no...
review_full: The food is excellent; the service is very good; the price is fair; and the experience is noteworthy but the name connotes nothing in English (means 'dad' in Italian). Recommended by the excellent hotel (Preciados), so we ventured in. Very close by but with no outdoor seating on a lovely evening following the coronation of Felipe. Bread and an excellent artichoke appetizer was served. Ordered the Mozarella e Pomodoro to split as a salad followed by the cappelli di zucca and girelle. Both entrees were excellent; mozarella would have been better with basil instead of arugula. House wine was fine. Surprised by the 'gratis' lemoncello at the end. And a tiny bit surprised by the small charge for the bread....didn't order it but did eat some (half) with the olive oil that we asked for...so we got a free artichoke appetizer and some lemoncello but paid for the bread....fair enough. Tax not included. Fair deal; fun evening due to the helpful owner/proprietor. Would definitely go back. Everyone else was speaking Spanish so definitely popular with the local crowd...and that makes it special too! Try it; you will not be disappointed. The family of six across the aisle had a great evening of pizza/spaghetti and something fizzy afterwards.

title_review: Fantastic, classic Italian cooking and great welcome
review_preview: We'd walked past the restaurant and it hadn't appealed to us but it was then ( thankfully!) recommended by our hotel . It has no outside seating but inside is fine , very busy with very few tourists but lots of local diners. The owner...
review_full: We'd walked past the restaurant and it hadn't appealed to us but it was then ( thankfully!) recommended by our hotel . It has no outside seating but inside is fine , very busy with very few tourists but lots of local diners. The owner speaks very good English and we had a great welcome. We ate pizza and spaghetti bolognese the first time and it was so good we returned the next day and ate lasagne and a different pizza. The food was fresh , tasty and served really quickly .You have to try the tiramisu - superb! The menu was varied and reasonably priced for a city centre restaurant with a good wine list too. HIghly recommended , much nicer than the regular tourist haunts just a few hundred yards away but seems to have missed the radar since it's tucked away on a side street just by the Opera plaza.

review_full: I really wanted to like this place, but it fell short. Their menu is very extensive....from simple pizza to fancy pasta to meat dishes (they are trying to please everyone). For our group, the food was pretty good but not great...my pasta with veggies looked great and it was pretty good but lacking complexity...not worth the asking price. No one complained about their meals, but no one seemed wowed either. The tiramisu was a disappointment...it was all cream and had little flavor. That said, there might be some gems somewhere on that huge menu. Service was friendly but inconsistent....some tables got better treatment and attention than others. It's modern inside. Noise levels can get pretty high. Decent wine choices. Overall, they try hard, but it's just too pricey for the quality. It's a fun place but don't expect to be wowed.

title_review: Tasty Italien spot near the house!
review_preview: Our foodie and loyal Trip Advisor friends made a reservation for a Friday night dinner for the four of us.  The restaurant filled up quickly and we were happy we had the forethought to make a reservation.  The menu was a little surprising as it...
review_full: Our foodie and loyal Trip Advisor friends made a reservation for a Friday night dinner for the four of us. The restaurant filled up quickly and we were happy we had the forethought to make a reservation. The menu was a little surprising as it was very large, so as a party we were concerned whether they could do the myriad of dishes presented well. I ordered the black truffle risotto (my favorite) and although the dish was flavorful, I was a little disheartened that the table next to us had the lovely addition of fresh truffle shavings and did not. My husband had the large stuffed seafood raviolis which were quite good, although not very complex in flavors.

review_preview: A favourite choice for special occasions, for both lunch and dinner, although the prices are not prohibitive for an enjoyable mid-week lunch with friends that will somehow feel special.  (Just  allow enough time to be able to indulge yourself fully - you'll want to.) The...
review_full: A favourite choice for special occasions, for both lunch and dinner, although the prices are not prohibitive for an enjoyable mid-week lunch with friends that will somehow feel special. (Just allow enough time to be able to indulge yourself fully - you'll want to.) The decor is elegant - not flashy - and the restaurant feels very comfortable, both indoors and, in the summer, on the large, covered and air conditioned terrace (That sounds paradoxical... but it's true. And it works beautifully.)  The food is top drawer, simple, fairly traditional Spanish although there are some wonderful and surprising specialities to try such as the tortilla with clams. Wine and copas (especially G&T) are all good - properly prepared and served.  I've eaten here on various occasions and never been disappointed by the food, service or atmosphere. Last time, a large group of well-known politicians and journalists were also dining there. But even that didn't spoil my dinner. A reliable fall-back for so many different situations, I've been there for business lunches, and with family and friends. It just works.

review_full: Originally, I was going to another restaurant which happened to be closed today. I noticed Nina Pasta Bar on my way there, and the simplicity of the menu immediately attracted my attention. Just when I was hesitating whether to give it try or not, the friendly staff pulled me in. I wish I remember her name. She makes the ambience inviting with her friendliness. I ordered an appetizer recommended by the staff and a capote ragout. The appetizer is really good and it matches with the pasta and my drink. By far, one of the best appetizer recommendation! If you come by, make sure you order capote ragout as not only it is super delicious but also you can tell all the preparation goes behind making this pasta. It‚Äôs one of a kind taste and only here! Overall, the portion is big. I have half of the pasta left for to-go.  I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone who visits Madrid. I would definitely come back next time in Madrid!

review_preview: .We've eaten at La Ancha (Vergara) 3 or 4 times. Most recently, we had a wonderful experience. We shared a flavorful dish of shrimp with garlic, ham and peas as a starter. Also delicious anchovies in olive oil. I had Merluza (hake), gently fried and...
review_full: .We've eaten at La Ancha (Vergara) 3 or 4 times. Most recently, we had a wonderful experience. We shared a flavorful dish of shrimp with garlic, ham and peas as a starter. Also delicious anchovies in olive oil. I had Merluza (hake), gently fried and served with squid ink sauce with a couple of perfectly cooked pieces of squid, one of my favorite fish dishes ever. I tasted my wife's steak, which was outsized, but perfectly cooked, rare, tender and flavorful. The carrot cake was unexceptional, but raspberries in a light sauce were very fine. We drank a terrific Rioja. The staff was great. I had missed an email saying they could not accommodate us for busy Saturday lunch, but they found a spot for us on the lovely terrace, which was sunny and warm on a cool February day. Our waiter was a seasoned professional, attentive but unobtrusive. This is a place where you can follow the waiter's guidance when ordering. Our group of three Spaniards and two Americans were all delighted with the food and the ambience as we enjoyed over three hours together.

We will go back, enough trial and error looking for the right place!

title_review: Interesting fusion cuisine but not for everyone!
review_preview: We had a great meal in this small but pleasant space. The service was a little surly (but we were a large international group of very thirsty and probably slightly picky diners). The cuisine is first class; imaginative and even a little off-the-wall and is...
review_full: We had a great meal in this small but pleasant space. The service was a little surly (but we were a large international group of very thirsty and probably slightly picky diners). The cuisine is first class; imaginative and even a little off-the-wall and is prepared with great attention to detail. However, since its focus is most definitely on Japanese cuisine and predominantly fish, it was difficult for those amongst us who were not fans of small slices of raw fish to find anything to appeal. Don't ask for bread to help fill the gap - they claimed not to have any! Also, the service was pretty slow and the amount of food minimal, so don't go there hungry! Overall, the food was exquisite, interesting and adventurous and I felt that other diners treated the cuisine and the place itself with considerably more reverence than we did - but it's not for everyone!

title_review: Great place for genuine French crepes in Madrid
review_preview: I found this crepes place walking down Huertas street and decided to have a coffee there as they had Illy (sometimes is difficult to find one in Madrid). It turned out the owner is from France and he is making the crepes himself. Variety of...
review_full: I found this crepes place walking down Huertas street and decided to have a coffee there as they had Illy (sometimes is difficult to find one in Madrid). It turned out the owner is from France and he is making the crepes himself. Variety of sweet and savory crepes, served in an original way. Try the Bounty (coconut). I have been there twice, great place to meet with friends and have a Sunday brunch. You can try cider there too. Small hidden place in the heart of Madrid. And also, they have French intercambio nights on Fridays which is nice to know.

review_preview: This is the best little fun restaurant in Madrid for French crepes. Just up the road from Atocha, on Calle Heurtes is Le Comptoir de la Crepe. A charming restaurant owned by a man from Toulouse France who has lived a parallel life to mine...
review_full: This is the best little fun restaurant in Madrid for French crepes. Just up the road from Atocha, on Calle Heurtes is Le Comptoir de la Crepe. A charming restaurant owned by a man from Toulouse France who has lived a parallel life to mine leaving his homeland to work and live in London, Dublin, San Diego, somewhere in souther Spain I didn‚Äôt catch and currently in Madrid. Because my work takes me all over the world I have eaten in all types of restaurants. When I am not with a client I am always in search of the not the best, but the most delectable and salivating foods from local restaurants. Why? Because these are the most interesting and vitally important to a local community.  Reading previous reviews this little place astonished diners from almost the very first crepe. Le Comptoir de la Crepe in its early days could be a marvel of palate defining savory or sweet crepes, flamb√©s and gametes couple with some great French cider. I had dinner there the first night I was in Madrid that appeared to take me back to a French coastal town restaurant I visited many years ago. There are no appetizers. There are small meals of savory crepes to start with that are poetry about light eating and an introduction to the restaurant and its pleasures. Le Comptoir is a wonderful place to eat by yourself but is so much more fun to eat at with someone you love or friends as you can share in the delights of what plate has come to your table - unexpected deliciousness! Dessert crepes and flamb√©s are even better. such excitement breeds real emotion with your fellow diners and have an effect on you for life as memories are made. This little restaurant rewards companionship and the senses without overindulgence allowing you to drink a flavorful Vino Tientto as you wander up the street after dinner. Le Comptoir is by all accounts a very personal restaurant.  The owner is the chef and wanders around tables making sure you are enjoying the food and atmosphere. In fact you could probably say that he is part of the atmosphere. Laughter rings out often from the front door right through the restaurant and it is pleasant and non-disturbing.I would recommend the duck crepes with cider to drink and a flamb√© for dessert. Take your time here and enjoy what it is offering. This place is special and will hold many memories for you until you return. I'd like you to have great memories of Madrid too, so please even visit this place for dessert before you leave.

review_preview: We own several restaurants in NYC, and food plays an important part in our lives. We love to travel and eating the local cusine is an important part of our vacation El Rincon de Esteban is a wonderful restaurant.  The food, the service and the...
review_full: We own several restaurants in NYC, and food plays an important part in our lives. We love to travel and eating the local cusine is an important part of our vacation  El Rincon de Esteban is a wonderful restaurant. The food, the service and the atmosphere all come together and provide a very pleasant dining experience. Everything we tired was excellent , fresh and top quality. I observed the wait staff being very plesant to some patrons that quite frankly did not deserve to be treated so graciously. Now that's a class act in of its self! The owner, Esteban, was on the floor and going from table to table to see how everyone was doing. We asked him his opinion on several dishes and to pick the Rose wine he felt would be best - he did not let us down. The food is traditional cusine of the region. The fish soup and the mushroom and seafood pie (more of a flan) were standouts. The roasted meats were succulant and our daughter's rice dish was savorary. The homemade fig ice cream and orange ice cream with chestnuts was one of the best frozen deserts I have ever had Yes, there is a charge for things such as bread and olives - but this is Europe, and it is what it is. However, the extra touches provided and not charged on the bill well made-up for some bread and olives. A bottle of cava, a plate of chocolates and a warm thank you from Esteban provided a perfect ending to a great meal.

title_review: Eat likes Spanish King at a moderate price
review_preview: This restaurant has high ranking in many website. I came here mainly because it open at 7pm instead of 8/9 pm as most of the restaurants in Madrid.I was surprise to see so many famous people photos inside the restaurant.This restaurant has history...
review_full: This restaurant has high ranking in many website. I came here mainly because it open at 7pm instead of 8/9 pm as most of the restaurants in Madrid. I was surprise to see so many famous people photos inside the restaurant. This restaurant has history and glory time in the past for sure. The boss is cheerful old man and he is very energetic and lovely.  I even saw a photo of Spanish King and queen and hand writing too. Tom Cruise and many famous football players were there too.  Eating here means you are eating a similar meal as a current Spanish king did.  I like the lamb shoulder here. It's very simple and very traditional. But it tasted very good. I had a spainish mix seafood rice ( paella). Which is good for share. We also ordered bone steak but I don't like it because it's age beef( boss did not notice me) . I know many people like age beef but not me. It's looked very good. Dessert is a must skip! I tried two but it's both were soso.  Overall, I am very happy to have a royal dinner at a very moderate price. I highly recommend you to order lamb shoulder and paella.

review_full: I happened upon this place one night when i got stuck in a downpour in Huertas and have been going back ever since. The atmosphere has that certain je ne sais quoi, perfect for a quiet evening spent jotting down ideas in a journal, a girls nightout fueled with lots of kir, or a romantic occasion. The savory and sweet crepes are wonderful, though as a foreigner in Madrid the salads are also a godsend when one needs a break from jamon and eggs. What really keeps me coming back though, is the owner Frank, a fantastic host who makes the experience much more akin to visiting an old friend that throws great dinner parties. I can't say enough good things about this place and highly recommend it!

review_full: I cannot speak highly enough of my families dining experience here. We arrived in Madrid somewhat late and walked in around 10:45pm and were greeted with open arms. Traditional Classic Madrid cuisine was served at it's finest. The place was full of locals. We had amazing wine at a reasonable price. Along with that the meal was spectacular and so authentic. The star of the show was the suckling pig, which was out of this world. We also had lamb, iberico ham, and steak. Many pictures on the wall from famous people. The owner was there dining with some friends and checked on us throughout the evening along with the fine waitstaff. One of the best meals in had on our 20 day trip through Spain/Portugal.

The interiors were romantic ( candles) and cosy and the service was impeccable . It has obviously been around for a long time so there is many photos on the walls . Just lovely .The lovely Thomas looked after me so well and assisted in my choices. It seemed that most diners were local so of you are looking for an authentic meal that is quite different to the many tapas bars then I suggest you try it. If you follow a gluten free diet he has gallette crepe flour (buckwheat). For a savory & a sweet crepe and a drink I usually pay around 10-12 euros... there are many options. that's just to give you an idea of the cost. the interior looks like a French bistro and there is always French radio playing in the background. If you want to try it out on a weekend night call first to see if you'll need a reservation. it can get filled quickly on the weekends (and with good reason!!).

On Sunday night, we just looked inside and it was full, every table filled, every seat taken. We were just about to leave when the phone rang. She came to us and said it would be 5 minutes, a cancellation, and we got a table. We had the Paella with chicken and some seafood. A mixed green salad and the house white wine. Enjoyed it immensely. Tuesday night after a long day of being a tourist at a museum, originally steak was on my mind. Just did not want to be overly indulgent. So we ordered a Monkfish for two, with garlic and potatoes. Again a mixed salad and the same white wine. The tray of olives and bread arrived first, soon followed by an amuse bouche. Then a small lemon sorbet, to cleanse the palate. Then the platter of a whole Monkfish was presented at the table and then served to us. Time passes as we enjoy our food. Then we finish and a dessert menu is five to us. I am in with two scoops of vanilla ice cream, she has one scoop, some flan, and strawberries. A small bottle of a Limoncillo is placed on the table and we drink a third. The bill is given and paid, handshakes around the table and we try to walk back to the Hotel.

review_preview: My boyfriend and I went to Madrid for a long weekend and had dinner at Le Comptoir de la Crepe on the first night. The restaurant's interior is really nice and the atmosphere was laid back and yet refined. I'm a huge fan of pancakes,...
review_full: My boyfriend and I went to Madrid for a long weekend and had dinner at Le Comptoir de la Crepe on the first night. The restaurant's interior is really nice and the atmosphere was laid back and yet refined. I'm a huge fan of pancakes, but the crepes on offer here are on an entirely different level: light, delicious, and there are so many different dishes to choose from (both savory and sweet). Each crepe arrived very quickly, and I found that two made for a perfect dinner without feeling stuffed afterwards. The friendly owner speaks English really well and helps you choose when you can't decide on which crepe to take. The drinks on offer were very good. I would definitely come back any time I visit Madrid!

The crepe itself was light and fluffy even though the menu warns of the difference of flour that is used. We had the fortune to sit at the table closest to the door and watch the master at his craft. We paired our crepe with a bottle of deliciously earthy dry sparkling cider and finished with a perfectly executed cappuccino. In a city of culinary wonders this restaurant stands out.

title_review: Simply Incredible!!!!! A Must in Spain!!
review_preview: When a good friend talked to me about Kabuki, he told me: ‚ÄúIn Spain there are only two Japanese restaurants: Kabuki and the rest!‚Äù, I decided to go (it has a Michelin Star) and I discovered the most spectacular Japanese I¬¥ve ever visited in the...
review_full: When a good friend talked to me about Kabuki, he told me: ‚ÄúIn Spain there are only two Japanese restaurants: Kabuki and the rest!‚Äù, I decided to go (it has a Michelin Star) and I discovered the most spectacular Japanese I¬¥ve ever visited in the world (and I can ensure that I have travel a lot as I am involved in international business and I have visited many Japanese restaurants). The place is small and a bit noisy, with a modern and friendly atmosphere. The service is impeccable and the mastery of Mario Pay√°n, the sushiman, really impressed me. The food is spectacular (instead of ordering, I always ask Mario to serve me what he wants; the experience is always amazing, and I recommend you to do the same). I also appreciate the atmosphere: young and business people enjoying the experience in a casual environment. The area outside (terrace) is great in the summer. The only problem is that if you try once, you will become addicted to it and now I go at least once a month. Regarding the price, it is not cheap, it is truth, but I¬¥m feed up of paying a lot for bad food in bad restaurants, especially Japanese. Here, in my opinion, the food really deserves the price you pay for it because they give you simply the best. So, don¬¥t hesitate to go and try the experience. My Last recommendation: don¬¥t forget to order a GinTonic after the dinner, especially if you are seated outside in the summer. They¬¥re simply great!

review_full: Last night i had dinner in this restaurant together with my girl friend and another couple. The experience was disapointing at best. The night was marred by an unhelpfull maitre who was not willing to compromise on anything culinery. Whilst i appreciate that the restaurant is japanese in essence,i cannot condone the maitre unwillingness to grill some of their tasty morsels for the benefit of those who do not like raw fish.  To add insult to injury the meal was further compounded by his unwillingless to separate the noodles from the soup. Had i been paying peanuts i would have expected monkeys but the meal was a wapping 480 euros and at 120 euros pp my disapointment is plainly palpable. The fact is i was going to propose to my girlfriend last night and had to do so in the hotel lobby. A planned special night turned into a near disaster. To conclude i cannot recommend this restaurant to anybody. Furthermore i can honestly state that having eaten in many michelin star restaurants this must rank as the lowest of the low!!

review_preview: I truly enjoyed this restaurant but it is most likely not for everybody. The food is a combination of Japanese with Spanish ingredients. So if you are looking for either cuisine, this could be kind of a shock (they have the usual rolls, sushi, etc...
review_full: I truly enjoyed this restaurant but it is most likely not for everybody. The food is a combination of Japanese with Spanish ingredients. So if you are looking for either cuisine, this could be kind of a shock (they have the usual rolls, sushi, etc but for this price I would go someplace else). However, for me, which enjoy Spanish food but am not a die-hard lover of Japanese food, really like it. Things like mozzarella tempura, Tokyo quesadilla, grilled calamari, spicy tuna, octopus rolls, BBQ beef rolls, garlic beef yaki and a sampler of different type of tuna are examples of what you can have. The big pluses that made me love this restaurant is the creative dishes (taste and combinations); the selection of sake (bigger than their wine lists) and overall service. The drawbacks is the complex menu ‚Äì too many dishes and it is awfully hard to understand whether you are ordering a tiny portion or something big enough to share, need a lot of coaching from the waiter and time to read through it; and the other thing is that it is expensive. Worth it in my opinion because we were a group of 8 people that truly enjoyed it but for the price, if you don‚Äôt like it, will not only leave a sour taste in your mouth. All in all it has to be one of my favorite restaurants in Madrid. Something that could better prepare you for the experience (which I found out later) is that they have in their website their menu with lots of pictures of the dishes, take a look at it and probably will spend less time reading in the restaurant

review_preview: Great atmosphere, service, and wine.  Food was just ok.  We did the tasting menu, which had a few items I wasn't a fan of....partridge and sea urchin.  The presentation and preparation were both very clean, as expected for this style of restaurant.  The toro was...
review_full: Great atmosphere, service, and wine. Food was just ok. We did the tasting menu, which had a few items I wasn't a fan of....partridge and sea urchin. The presentation and preparation were both very clean, as expected for this style of restaurant. The toro was my favorite, and was literally a pile of toro, nothing else. I would have been happy with just that. The tasting menu finished with churros con chocolate, which may be too far off course for a Japanese restaurant. They were small and dainty - nothing like you get elsewhere in Madrid.  The service was excellent and the sommelier had excellent recommendations. The wine she picked was great.  Overall, this was a good meal, but not my favorite. If I went back, I would just order sushi from the menu rather than the tasting menu.

review_preview: We were three people and decided to it in the bar, thinking that we would interact with the sushi chefs. Wrong, you only talk to the waiters, and the chefs do not pay any attention to you. Instead, the chefs check every girl that enters...
review_full: We were three people and decided to it in the bar, thinking that we would interact with the sushi chefs. Wrong, you only talk to the waiters, and the chefs do not pay any attention to you. Instead, the chefs check every girl that enters the restaurant door and comment on their outfits and bodies. Very unprofessional. My friends asked to be served whatever the chefs wanted, which in a Japanese restaurant means a lot of things out of the regular menu. Wrong again. Everything served was in the menu, which was very disappointing. The sushi is innovative and the quality is outstanding, even the chefs were smelling some of the fish before cutting it. The sashimi cuts were very well done, the combination of flavors and presentation was beautiful. Service was very good and attentive, although some times they did not know what they were serving and had to check with the chefs (remember everything was from the menu). I might come back only for the difference of the flavors, although for sure I will not sit at the bar. I would skip the miso soup, at paying 6 EUR for a very salty cup is not worthy. I would not have the tempura again as it misses seasoning and flavor both in the batter as in the prawns. The desserts did not impress me either. None of this is worth my money.

review_preview: Kabuki is a Japanese restaurant in Madrid with outdoor and indoor seating, but it is very busy, so I recomend making reservations. They focus mainly on sushi, especially nigiri and sashimi, but they also have some soups and appetizers that utilize sushi within them. The...
review_full: Kabuki is a Japanese restaurant in Madrid with outdoor and indoor seating, but it is very busy, so I recomend making reservations. They focus mainly on sushi, especially nigiri and sashimi, but they also have some soups and appetizers that utilize sushi within them. The cooking is excellent, I would especially recomend their sukiaki soup because of its delicious meat and broth. The sushi is expertly prepared with but one fault, that has nothing to do with the chefs' capabilities: it is located far from any ocean, and therefore the fish is not very fresh. Everything about this restaurant is great and even though the fish isn't so fresh it still has a great flavor although lacking in tenderness and texture. The restaurant is very expensive, but the food is quite good.

title_review: The best sushi I have ever eaten
review_preview: There are few times when I would use such superlative language but the "chef's menu" that my son and I ate together last week at Kabuki was not only the best sushi I have eaten, but one of the best meals I have eaten. Unlike...
review_full: There are few times when I would use such superlative language but the "chef's menu" that my son and I ate together last week at Kabuki was not only the best sushi I have eaten, but one of the best meals I have eaten.  Unlike its associated restaurant in Madrid, the Kabuki Wellington, the orginal Kabuki is funky, lively, informal and fun yet at the same time superbly professional in its service and presentation of each plate. The menu/carte is very extensive and to be honest I would not know where to start ordering as this is both Japanese and Spanish fusion sushi made from the finest a freshest fish, seafood, meat and vegetables that are available in Spain. So we made it easy for ourselves by taking up the recommendation of a menu, that is not listed or written anywhere, in which the chef creates a menu with a developing scale of favours from the most delicate oysters to a fully flavoured slow cooked marinated meat on the bone. Menu can be adapted according to your dietary needs or preferences and how much you would like to eat. We chose the full monty! We counted 15 courses at the end plus the welcoming amuse bouche. We chose not to have desert....there was neither space nor a desire to lose the other flavours we had been treated to over the long and exiting evening of gastronomy. Counting our drinks of beer and sake the itemised bill listing each dish and its cost was 111 euros each. Some may say this is expensive but truly this would be way more in London, New York or Tokyo. We left happy having spoken to the owner/chef (the kitchen is completely open) with a beautful printed personal copy of the menu we had eaten and a promise to ourselves to return soon. Given the number of people the chef greeted as old friends Kabuki is a place with its own returning fan club. We have just joined it.

review_preview: One of my personal favorites for fish and sea food in Madrid. Elegant, classy, quiet, comfortable, efficient and friendly staff. Above all: high-quality, fresh and masterly prepared fish. Now: all this comes for a price, but it is absolutely worth the last penny.My favorite...
review_full: One of my personal favorites for fish and sea food in Madrid. Elegant, classy, quiet, comfortable, efficient and friendly staff. Above all: high-quality, fresh and masterly prepared fish. Now: all this comes for a price, but it is absolutely worth the last penny. My favorite is the "lubina a la sal", which combines an outstanding unmasked taste with a very healthy fare. But most of the selections are just as good. Alvari√±o wine is highly recommended for all seafood and fish. I visit the place whenever I'm in Madrid and will continue to do so. You won't regret the experience.

title_review: Great food with home away from home service.
review_preview: Went to this restaurant which was recommended by the hotel and my lord was it an excellent experience.  We walked in through the wrong there were I was greeted with a warm smile of a fatherly looking gentleman whose name I cannot recall. He did...
review_full: Went to this restaurant which was recommended by the hotel and my lord was it an excellent experience. We walked in through the wrong there were I was greeted with a warm smile of a fatherly looking gentleman whose name I cannot recall. He did not point me to the right entrance but rather walked with me to it and inside. There I was serviced by a young man from Colombia name Johan. While speaking with Johan I learned he had worked at one of my usual spots in New Jersey named Meson Madrid. Johan is super friendly and service savvy. Well the whole staff is but something special about Johan and this great place. If you go there definitely have the Gallego Oysters which are amazingly fresh and delicious. The Ox Tale is insanely amazing actually cooked by a fellow Dominican name Manuel from Bani. I got to speak to Manuel as the gentleman who escorted me in also introduce me Tobin as I praised the Taste of the tail. And try the pudin de pan for dessert. My suggestion don‚Äôt even think about the menu just let them order for you and everything will be to your palate‚Äôs delight. Oh yeah Johan can make one heck of a Manhattan. Gracias Johan hasta la pr√≥xima.

title_review: Top seafood quality and outstanding service!
review_preview: Went to Carta Marina for a business dinner and wow I was really impressed with both the quality of the food and the great service. If you do like seafood this is the place to go. From oysters, prawns and fish everything we had was...
review_full: Went to Carta Marina for a business dinner and wow I was really impressed with both the quality of the food and the great service. If you do like seafood this is the place to go. From oysters, prawns and fish everything we had was very fresh, well presented (they even adjusted the portions to our party size so no fight for the last morsel) and very flavorful. The service is what you can expect from a top notch restaurant: attentive but not obstructive, from wine serving to replacing plates with each dish. The place itself is very nice and comfortable. Definitely a top destination for seafood lovers in Madrid.

But while waiting you can enjoy some nice wine or sangria accompanied by wonderful crispy white bread with olive oil, olives and some tasteful Iberian dry ham. Furthermore the hosts were wonderfully helpful and professional. We all really enjoyed our time here and will definitely come back for our next visit of Madrid.

review_preview: Was recommended this restaurant by hotel concierge.  Arrived at 10 pm and restaurant was empty.  Food was very expensive and mediocre at best.  Ordered an approximate 38 euro bottle of red spanish wine.  Was told that they didn't have the wine, but had a similar...
review_full: Was recommended this restaurant by hotel concierge. Arrived at 10 pm and restaurant was empty. Food was very expensive and mediocre at best. Ordered an approximate 38 euro bottle of red spanish wine. Was told that they didn't have the wine, but had a similar bottle for the same price. Wine was served from decanter. Believing we were drinking a 38 euro bottle of wine, ordered another one. When bill came, were charged over 100 euro per bottle of wine. We objected, but all of a sudden there became an English language barrier, and management called over. Management insisted that's what we ordered. Then owner came over and asked how much tip did we want to add to the bill, that is was customary to add 10 percent. Being our first night in Spain (which the restaurant was fully aware of), and not being familiar yet with spanish tipping customs, we foolishly complied and left another 40 euro. Have never felt so violated in my life! All I can say is "stay away. stay far, far away!!!)

review_preview: I truly love this restaurant. I love Japanese food and always seek the best Japanese restaurants in major cities like NYC and London (and I will soon check off Tokyo from my list). In Madrid, Kabuki is by far the best Japanese restaurant. It has...
review_full: I truly love this restaurant. I love Japanese food and always seek the best Japanese restaurants in major cities like NYC and London (and I will soon check off Tokyo from my list). In Madrid, Kabuki is by far the best Japanese restaurant. It has classic Japanese fish dishes using only the freshest ingredients. In addition, and perhaps the reason I love this restaurant, it has a remarkable ability to fusion Japanese food with key Spanish ingredients. To fusion together two types of food is very difficult to get right but Kabuki executes it perfectly. This restaurant has received a Michelin star and it is well deserved. The wine list includes some of Spain's most sought after (and hard to get) white and red wines. I go back to this restaurant every time I can.

Most of the food is probably good but the prices are so outrageous that I only had a coke (‚Ç¨3 for 250ml.) and a cold soup called Somen (‚Ç¨13). The noodles were not much better than what you get in a package of Ramen and the soup was like the stock you would make using the packets that come with the Ramen. If money is no object I am sure you will enjoy this restaurant, but I am sure there is better value available.

Don't expect to pay less than 50 ‚Ç¨ per person + wine and also don't expect the place to be quiet... That's probably what I liked less... review_preview: I cannot believe this place is rated 4.5 out of 5 on TripAdvisor and has 1 star at Michelin... it's just a lie or the chef was on vacation...After 10 days of traveling around Andalusia and Castilla and eating Spanish food, we were craving...
review_full: I cannot believe this place is rated 4.5 out of 5 on TripAdvisor and has 1 star at Michelin... it's just a lie or the chef was on vacation... After 10 days of traveling around Andalusia and Castilla and eating Spanish food, we were craving Japenenese food. We searched online for the one of the best Japenese restaurant and found Kabuki. We were immidiately disappointed by over salted Udon soup ... Then by the Sushis with a rice that had a mushy texture, with too much rice vinegar which overpowered the delicate taste of the fish.  Fresh quality fish has a natural fresh taste but we could not find the flavor in each fish. They also used sauces that killed the flavor instead of enhancing the flavor of the fish. For example, sweet eel sauce with octopus? All you taste is the sauce!  We also ordered Wagyu beef and it was tasty. The meat was medium rare with a nice texture and the sauces complimented the flavor of the beef.  Without the beef, I would rate this place with 2 stars. I mean, how can you fail to make good rice? All they need to do is try it before serving it.  Instead of constantly laughing and whispering, cookers at bar and waiters should look at the disappointment that was displayed on a big majority of the customer faces, and try to improve... but perhaps they don't care, and already know the kind of food they are preparing... :( PS: 3 glasses of wine + 1 soup + 6 sushis + 10 slices of Wagyu + 1 desert ... of barely standard food = 150 ‚Ç¨ at Kabuki.

title_review: Tiny place, Great food, Awesome prices
review_preview: Smallest pizzeria ever with perfect location.Right in the middle of the partying, shopping area of Madrid. With very nice pizzas and pastas. The food is awesome and the prices are a bargain!!! You will not eat cheaper than this without going to McDonalds (not...
review_full: Smallest pizzeria ever with perfect location. Right in the middle of the partying, shopping area of Madrid. With very nice pizzas and pastas. The food is awesome and the prices are a bargain!!! You will not eat cheaper than this without going to McDonalds (not even there!) Pizzas 4/5 Euros, Pastas 5/6 Euros.  The place is packed all day long and there is limited seating space. Always on stools at the bars. Expect to be rubbed against by people trying to get to the end of the place... but you will be concentrated on the food so, you will not be bothered. Tiramisu is homemade and ok. Service simply perfect: They are all smiles and help! Thanks Fina! Great place for a quick dinner before clubbing.

title_review: Friendly, Decent Food - Watch for EXTRAS
review_preview: Was recommended by hotel concierge as typical Madrid representative.  Staff was incredibly friendly, chatty (even though we spoke english and they did not).  Made you feel right at home.It was a short walk from the Westin Palace on a quiet side street.  I had...
review_full: Was recommended by hotel concierge as typical Madrid representative. Staff was incredibly friendly, chatty (even though we spoke english and they did not). Made you feel right at home. It was a short walk from the Westin Palace on a quiet side street.  I had Sea Bass which was good. Grilled well with basic green beans and roasted potatoes. Wife stuck with a salad. Not much too it but very good. Overall the meal was good but not overwhelming. Be aware that they load the table with Extras such as pate, breads, sardines and such. We thought they were part of the meal and munched. Bill came and it was all on there. Apparently you must tell them when you come in to remove it or you are charged. Kind of cheesy but typical of most tourist restuarants we went too. We noticed several "regulars" sit and ask them be removed - we should have done since we did not like most of the table snacks (sardines, olives, and strong pate). My advice is stick to paella wherever you go if you are from the states. Couple of notes: 1) Meal was pricey. With a house bottle of spanish red wine the bill ran $200USD 2) Dont be in a hurry. We are used to US restuarants and keep waiting for fast and attentive. Takes us a couple days of detox to remember that Eurpoeans and especially Spanish take long, lesiurely meals. 2 hours is not uncommon. Service reflects this. We relaxed quickly and starting enjoying talking and meeting people around us.

title_review: The Owner and the Food: Excellent
review_preview: So we were going to go to one of the more well known tourist places when we were in Madrid (one that is among the oldest in Europe.) However, we were really wanting something closer to the Hotel Villa Real where we were staying. The...
review_full: So we were going to go to one of the more well known tourist places when we were in Madrid (one that is among the oldest in Europe.) However, we were really wanting something closer to the Hotel Villa Real where we were staying. The concierge recommended this place. Said it was true it is not that old, only about 50 years old. Dare I say we were turning out the lights with the staff by the time we ate and drank for several hours. We were treated by the owner and the staff like long lost relatives-the ones you might really like not the other kind. Yes, they were mostly full the night we ate there.The food is excellent, the wine list extensive and not overpriced, the desserts and ports again excellent. It is a "must" experience. I would not go to Madrid without trying to dine there again.

review_preview: Spanish Chef Ricardo Sanz puts its Japanese culinary wizardry on display at this unbelievable restaurant in Madrid. This is haute cuisine at its best. Although, I am sure you would enjoy tasting any of the customary sushi-sashimi dishes, the price you pay at this restaurant...
review_full: Spanish Chef Ricardo Sanz puts its Japanese culinary wizardry on display at this unbelievable restaurant in Madrid. This is haute cuisine at its best. Although, I am sure you would enjoy tasting any of the customary sushi-sashimi dishes, the price you pay at this restaurant is best justified by tasting the unique Japanese fusion entrees in the menu. For the first visit (believe me. You will return) the optimal way to immerse yourself into Chef Sanz's artistry is to order the KABUKI MENU. It is a 10 course "degustacion" menu (don't be afraid. each dish is sized reasonably) representing a true "magic carpet" ride through the culinary space of this audacious and creative chef.  We accompanied the menu with a choice from an impressive list of notable small champagne and cava wine producers. The champagne we tried was outstanding, holding its own very well against traditionally known expensive champagnes. KABUKI will provide with a unique and unforgettable dinning experience but be prepared to pay in the order of $100 per person including sake or wine.

title_review: The most inexpensive & best Pizza & Pasta in Madrid
review_preview: Don¬¥t expect any frills here!!! This is a quaint small neighborhood bar style restaurant (no tables). Vesuvio reminds me of Japanese noodle restaurant Sapporo in N.Y. but in truly Italian style. This place has been open for thirty years and nothing has changed, "don¬¥t fix...
review_full: Don¬¥t expect any frills here!!! This is a quaint small neighborhood bar style restaurant (no tables). Vesuvio reminds me of Japanese noodle restaurant Sapporo in N.Y. but in truly Italian style. This place has been open for thirty years and nothing has changed, "don¬¥t fix it if it ain¬¥t broke". It was so nice to walk in the place after almost 8 years and still find that Nino¬¥s (owner, passed away 10 year ago) spirit is still there. Vesuvio ia straight off of Gran V√≠a on Calle Hortaleza 4. I do not know how is food quality, of course, but the absence of reliability with customer is not a good indicator.

Second time here over the past few years and each time we were treated like old customers and old friends by Sr. Esteban and staff. What gracious people and what good Spanish food. The gaspacho was memorable with goodies added as per your choice. Menu translations to English. Celebrities dine there on occasion according to pictures on the wall. We were seated at Queen Sofia's table and our picture was taken with Sr. Esteban included. The price was quite fair. Dinner for two with a couple of martinis for less than 100 U.S.  We are light eaters but had a full meal with desert and coffee but no tapas. Great people. Great place. Great food. You don't survive over 50 years without having something to offer. This place does. I'd go back in a Madrid minute!

review_preview: It was our last night in Madrid before leaving to Barcelona the following morning.  We wanted to eat somewhere that had ambiance, good food, and personality.  Boy did we luck out!  We arrived around 20:30 and the restaurant was already full.  Dinner is usually a...
review_full: It was our last night in Madrid before leaving to Barcelona the following morning. We wanted to eat somewhere that had ambiance, good food, and personality. Boy did we luck out! We arrived around 20:30 and the restaurant was already full. Dinner is usually a late evening event in Spain. We wanted Paella and El Rincon de Estaban was listed as a restaurant with good ratings for paella. The restaurant was purchased by a great young couple (young by my standards), Jesus & Maira. Maira runs the front of the house and Jesus oversees the kitchen. The restaurant was lively with conversations and [mainly] locals and we immediately felt at home. The d√©cor had a cozy feel with photos on all the walls from well know people who have eaten there. Our paella was cooked to perfection and the wine certainly didn't hurt the experience. I wouldn't hesitate to dine here for other items listed on the menu. Seeing other dishes being delivered to other tables looked appetizing and mouth watering. All I can say, is this is a restaurant that we‚Äôve added to our contacts for future visits.

review_full: From the moment we arrived, we were made to feel welcomed in a small, intimately run restaurant. The gentlemen who runs the show and who is featured with pictures on the wall of what we suppose are famous Spanish diners was very friendly and helpful. The menu is typically Spanish. We were there for a late lunch (even though it was 3PM, there were still many diners as meals occur on the later side and all seemed to be speaking Spanish). The octopus was beautifully grilled. We were having a small-ish lunch and ordered only one main dish each. The (we presume) owner still brought us complementary limoncello and a delicious chocolate finger snack once we requested the check. It would have been lovely for dinner, though the lights were bright, and if they don't tone them down in the evening, it would be an unusually well lit restaurant.

review_preview: This is the first time i have ever written a review but was so appauled, I felt I had to warn people. We booked for 30 people well in advance as thought it would be difficult to for anywhere to accomodate us and said we...
review_full: This is the first time i have ever written a review but was so appauled, I felt I had to warn people. We booked for 30 people well in advance as thought it would be difficult to for anywhere to accomodate us and said we wanted to pay around 20 euros per head for food. It was to celebrate a 50th Birthday. Hotel recomended and as our hotel was fabulous we thought it would be fine. We were the only people in there and the actual restaurant had a lovely atmosphere. On the tables when we arrived were bowls of olives and bread sticks and they had carafes of still chilled water (tap not bottled). Only 8 of the 30 had starters and rest had mains only. The food was not good but we thought it was because there were a lot of us. They then brought round a shot glass of yellow stuff which was like parafin, we had not ordered this and assumed it was complimentary. No one had dessert. To our horror the bill came to 2500 euros 86 euros per head. They had charged us 90 euros for water, 350 euros for the olives, and 280 for the yellow stuff, none of which we had ordered. 2 x vodka and tonic 25 euros, and wine and beer ( i had one beer and no wine) total 680 euros. We are a very easy to please bunch of 40-50 year olds but felt like we had been mugged. it was a total set up. The price did not match the standard of food. They knocked off 45 euros for water when we complained but laughed at us. Needless to say the next night we went to a different restaurant, had great food, 3 courses and drinks etc for 25 euro a head! Highly recommend 'Suzannas' round the corner. DONT GIVE THESE CROOKS ANY MORE BUSINESS!

We were shocked to see that it was charged 25 euros in the bill since we had a very good labeled wine for 18 euros the previous time.  It‚Äôs a shame to lose a customer like that.

review_full: Visited Esteban's in 2014 and 2018, and virtually no change in the excellent food, customer service, and atmosphere. A Madrid icon, popular with locals yet friendly to visitors. review_full: Don't be put off by the small, narrow appearance of this pizza place. Although there are only stools to sit on (no table and chairs for a more formal sit-down meal), this is without a doubt the best pizza in Madrid. The pizzas are smaller than some places but the perfect size for one person. The base is slightly thicker than the super thin Italian bases you get in most places and the pizzas are packed with lots of topping. Delicious food, cheaper than most pizza places in Madrid and friendly staff.

review_preview: We stumbled upon this great place by accident. It turned out to be really good and helped us so much with a vegetarian teenager who was struggling to find things she liked to eat in Madrid. The pizza was really good and the pasta was...
review_full: We stumbled upon this great place by accident. It turned out to be really good and helped us so much with a vegetarian teenager who was struggling to find things she liked to eat in Madrid. The pizza was really good and the pasta was also decent. It is tiny and you have to stake out your seats as other customers leave, so you kind of form a self policing line. But it didn't take long to get a place even on a crowded night (during a festival). You order over the counter and the food comes pretty quickly. There is also a take out window opening to outside, so you could order and take things to go. We ended up going twice during our stay in Madrid.

Water closet downstairs is a shared space and nice enough. sayings stenciled all over the walls and ceiling are enjoyable and entertaining.
